(2) Gain-of-function: Co-transfect the minigene with an RBP-X expression plasmid. If RBP-X promotes exon 7 inclusion, RT-PCR with primers in exons 6 and 8 should show increased inclusion isoform (exon 6-7-8) relative to the skipping isoform (exon 6-8). (3) Loss-of-function: Transfect the minigene into cells depleted of RBP-X (by siRNA/shRNA knockdown or CRISPR knockout). Exon 7 inclusion should decrease. (4) Controls: Include a mutant minigene where the predicted RBP-X binding site (usually identified by CLIP-seq or computational prediction) is mutated. If RBP-X acts directly, exon 7 inclusion should not respond to RBP-X overexpression in the mutant minigene. (5) Direct binding: EMSA or UV-crosslinking with labeled RNA probes containing the binding site would confirm direct RBP-X-RNA interaction.

questions.question: The ribosome has three tRNA binding sites: A (aminoacyl), P (peptidyl), and E (exit). During translation termination, release factors mimic the structure of tRNAs. In bacteria, how do RF1 and RF2 recognize stop codons, and what role does RF3 play?
options: RF1 recognizes the stop codon while RF2 cleaves the peptidyl-tRNA bond; RF3 exports the released peptide

RF1 recognizes UAA and UAG, RF2 recognizes UAA and UGA, through specific protein motifs that read the stop codon in the A site; RF3 is a GTPase that facilitates release of RF1/RF2 after peptide release
RF1 and RF2 both recognize all three stop codons equally; RF3 catalyzes peptide bond hydrolysis
RF3 is the primary stop codon recognition factor; RF1 and RF2 are recycling factors
questions.explanation: Bacterial translation termination involves two classes of release factors with distinct roles: Class I release factors (RF1 and RF2) directly recognize stop codons and catalyze peptide release. RF1 recognizes UAA and UAG through a conserved PVT (Pro-Val-Thr) tripeptide motif, while RF2 recognizes UAA and UGA through a SPF (Ser-Pro-Phe) motif. Both contain a universally conserved GGQ (Gly-Gly-Gln) motif that enters the peptidyl transferase center and triggers hydrolysis of the ester bond between the peptide chain and the P-site tRNA. The glutamine residue is methylated and positions a water molecule for nucleophilic attack on the peptidyl-tRNA ester bond. Crystal structures show that RF1/RF2 have an overall shape and size remarkably similar to tRNA (molecular mimicry), allowing them to fit into the A site. Class II release factor (RF3) is a GTPase that does not directly recognize stop codons. After peptide release, RF3-GTP binds the ribosome and promotes conformational changes that accelerate dissociation of RF1/RF2 from the post-termination complex. RF3-GDP then dissociates. In eukaryotes, a single class I factor (eRF1) recognizes all three stop codons, and eRF3 functions analogously to bacterial RF3.

questions.question: Trans-splicing is an unusual form of RNA processing found in certain organisms such as trypanosomes and C. elegans. How does trans-splicing differ from conventional cis-splicing?
options: In trans-splicing, exons from two separate pre-mRNA molecules are joined together; in trypanosomes, a short spliced leader (SL) RNA is trans-spliced to the 5' end of many different mRNAs, providing a common 5' exon and a trimethylguanosine cap
Trans-splicing joins exons that are far apart on the same pre-mRNA molecule
Trans-splicing occurs in the cytoplasm rather than the nucleus
Trans-splicing uses DNA ligase instead of the spliceosome
questions.explanation: Trans-splicing is a specialized form of RNA processing where exons from two independently transcribed pre-RNA molecules are ligated together, in contrast to cis-splicing where exons from the same pre-mRNA are joined. In trypanosomes (e.g., Trypanosoma brucei): (1) A small spliced leader (SL) RNA (~140 nt) is transcribed from tandemly repeated SL RNA genes. (2) The 39-nucleotide SL exon from this small RNA is trans-spliced onto the 5' end of virtually all trypanosome mRNAs. (3) This provides every mRNA with a common 5' leader sequence carrying a hypermethylated cap (cap 4, with a trimethylguanosine and additional methylations). (4) The mechanism uses a modified splicing reaction: the SL RNA provides the 5' splice site and its outron (analogous to an intron), while the pre-mRNA provides the branch point and 3' splice site. A Y-shaped intermediate (rather than a lariat) is formed. In C. elegans, approximately 70% of mRNAs receive one of two SL sequences (SL1 or SL2). SL2 trans-splicing specifically occurs on downstream genes in operons, resolving polycistronic transcripts into individual mRNAs. Trans-splicing has also been documented at low frequency in mammals and Drosophila, where it can generate chimeric mRNAs from separate genes.

questions.question: A researcher performs a toeprinting (primer extension inhibition) assay to map the position of ribosomes on an mRNA. She finds that in the presence of the antibiotic kasugamycin, the 30S ribosomal subunit still binds to the mRNA but the toeprint signal shifts from +16 (relative to the A of AUG) to a broader, less defined pattern. What does this result suggest about kasugamycin's mechanism of action?
options: Kasugamycin inhibits the stable positioning of the initiator tRNA in the P site, so the 30S subunit binds the mRNA but cannot properly lock onto the start codon, resulting in imprecise positioning
Kasugamycin prevents 30S subunit from binding mRNA entirely
Kasugamycin causes ribosomes to aggregate on the mRNA at multiple random positions
Kasugamycin converts the 30S subunit into a 50S subunit
questions.explanation: Toeprinting (primer extension inhibition) is a technique that maps the 3' boundary of ribosome-mRNA complexes. A radiolabeled DNA primer is annealed downstream of the ribosome binding site and extended by reverse transcriptase. When the enzyme encounters the ribosome, it stops, producing a defined band on a gel. For properly initiated 30S-mRNA complexes, the toeprint typically appears at position +16 relative to the A of the AUG start codon, reflecting the 3' boundary of the 30S subunit when the P site is occupied by initiator tRNA at the start codon. When kasugamycin is present: (1) The 30S subunit can still associate with the mRNA (toeprint signal is present), but the signal is shifted and broadened. (2) This indicates that the 30S subunit binds the Shine-Dalgarno region but cannot stably position the initiator fMet-tRNA in the P site paired with the AUG codon. (3) Kasugamycin specifically inhibits translation initiation by interfering with the interaction between the P-site codon and the initiator tRNA anticodon, without preventing 30S-mRNA association. (4) The imprecise toeprint reflects the 30S subunit sliding or oscillating on the mRNA without locking into a defined position. This contrasts with antibiotics like edeine, which allow precise start codon recognition but prevent 50S subunit joining.

questions.question: Ribosome recycling after translation termination is essential for maintaining the pool of free ribosomal subunits. In bacteria, ribosome recycling factor (RRF) works with EF-G to dissociate the post-termination complex. What is the structural basis for RRF's function?
options: RRF has a tRNA-like L-shaped structure that enters the A site of the ribosome; together with EF-G-dependent GTP hydrolysis, it promotes dissociation of the 70S ribosome into 30S and 50S subunits
RRF binds mRNA and pulls it out of the ribosome, causing subunit dissociation
RRF chelates Mg2+ ions that hold the ribosomal subunits together
RRF is a protease that degrades ribosomal proteins to disassemble the ribosome
questions.explanation: After translation termination and peptide release, the post-termination complex consists of the 70S ribosome bound to mRNA with a deacylated tRNA in the P site. This complex must be disassembled (recycled) to release the ribosomal subunits for new rounds of translation. The bacterial ribosome recycling pathway involves: (1) RRF binding: RRF has a remarkable tRNA-mimicry structure — it is L-shaped with two domains that correspond to the anticodon stem-loop and acceptor stem of tRNA. This shape allows RRF to enter the ribosomal A site, similar to how tRNAs and release factors bind. (2) EF-G binding: EF-G-GTP binds the ribosome in the presence of RRF. GTP hydrolysis by EF-G drives a conformational change that translocates RRF from the A site to the P site. (3) Subunit dissociation: This translocation event disrupts inter-subunit bridges, forcing the 50S subunit to dissociate from the 30S subunit. The deacylated tRNA and mRNA remain initially associated with the 30S subunit. (4) IF3 (initiation factor 3) then binds the free 30S subunit, displacing the deacylated tRNA and mRNA, and preventing reassociation with the 50S subunit. The 30S-IF3 complex is now ready for a new round of initiation. In eukaryotes, ribosome recycling uses ABCE1 (an ABC-type ATPase), reflecting the different evolutionary paths of the recycling machinery.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about mutations and their effects on gene expression:
S1: A silent (synonymous) mutation always has no effect on protein function or gene expression
S2: A conservative missense mutation replaces an amino acid with one having similar chemical properties and is less likely to disrupt protein function than a non-conservative change
S3: Insertions and deletions of three nucleotides (or multiples of three) within a coding region do not cause frameshifts
S4: A mutation in the -10 region (Pribnow box) of a bacterial promoter would likely increase transcription by enhancing RNA polymerase binding
options: S1-False, S2-True, S3-True, S4-False
S1-True, S2-True, S3-True, S4-False
S1-False, S2-True, S3-False, S4-False
S1-False, S2-False, S3-True, S4-True
questions.explanation: S1 is FALSE: While synonymous mutations do not change the amino acid sequence, they can still affect gene expression and protein function through several mechanisms: (a) Codon usage bias — a synonymous change to a rare codon can reduce translation efficiency and rate. (b) mRNA secondary structure — the nucleotide change can alter mRNA folding, affecting stability, splicing, or ribosome accessibility. (c) Exonic splicing enhancers/silencers — synonymous mutations can disrupt ESE or create ESS sequences, causing exon skipping. (d) Translation kinetics — changes in local translation speed can affect co-translational protein folding. S2 is TRUE: Conservative missense mutations replace amino acids with chemically similar ones (e.g., Asp→Glu, both acidic; Leu→Ile, both hydrophobic). These are less likely to disrupt protein structure because the replacement amino acid can often fulfill similar roles in hydrogen bonding, hydrophobic packing, or charge interactions. Non-conservative changes (e.g., Gly→Arg, small nonpolar to large positive) are more likely to disrupt folding and function. S3 is TRUE: In-frame insertions/deletions (3n nucleotides) add or remove whole codons without disrupting the reading frame of downstream codons. The protein gains or loses amino acids at that position, but the rest of the sequence is unaffected. S4 is FALSE: Most mutations in the -10 region (TATAAT consensus) would decrease transcription because the -10 region is essential for sigma factor recognition and DNA melting. Most random mutations would move the sequence further from the consensus, reducing sigma binding affinity.

questions.question: Eukaryotic cells contain three RNA polymerases (Pol I, II, III), each transcribing distinct gene classes. Alpha-amanitin from Amanita phalloides mushrooms is a potent differential inhibitor. At low concentrations (1 microgram/mL), it inhibits RNA Pol II. At high concentrations (10 microgram/mL), it also inhibits RNA Pol III. RNA Pol I is resistant. How can alpha-amanitin be used experimentally to determine which polymerase transcribes a specific gene?
options: Use alpha-amanitin as a mutagen to create polymerase-deficient cell lines

Treat cells with low-dose alpha-amanitin to selectively inhibit Pol II; if the target RNA disappears, it is a Pol II transcript. If unaffected at low dose but disappears at high dose, it is a Pol III transcript. If unaffected at both, it is a Pol I transcript
Inject alpha-amanitin into the cytoplasm to test whether nuclear or cytoplasmic transcription is affected
Add alpha-amanitin to purified RNA polymerase preparations and measure DNA binding
questions.explanation: Alpha-amanitin is an invaluable experimental tool because of its differential sensitivity profile across the three eukaryotic RNA polymerases. The experimental approach exploits these concentration-dependent effects: (1) At low concentrations (~1 ug/mL): Only RNA Pol II is inhibited. Pol II transcribes all protein-coding genes (mRNAs), most snRNAs (U1-U5), and some snoRNAs. If a target RNA's synthesis is blocked at this concentration, it is a Pol II product. (2) At intermediate-high concentrations (~10 ug/mL): RNA Pol III is also inhibited. Pol III transcribes tRNAs, 5S rRNA, U6 snRNA, 7SL RNA (SRP RNA), and other small RNAs. Transcripts that persist at low dose but are eliminated at high dose are Pol III products. (3) At any concentration: RNA Pol I is resistant (varies by organism — in some species Pol I shows intermediate sensitivity). Pol I transcribes the 45S pre-rRNA (which is processed into 18S, 5.8S, and 28S rRNAs). Alpha-amanitin binds in the bridge helix region of the largest subunit (Rpb1 in Pol II), trapping the polymerase in a translocation-incompetent state. Structural differences in this region between the three polymerases account for the differential sensitivity. This approach was historically important for classifying newly discovered RNA species.

questions.question: During translation, the ribosome maintains reading frame fidelity with remarkable accuracy. However, certain mRNA sequences can induce programmed -1 ribosomal frameshifting, which is essential for some viral gene expression. What mRNA elements are required for efficient -1 frameshifting?
options: A modified nucleotide (m6A) at the frameshift site that disrupts normal decoding

A heptanucleotide slippery sequence (typically X XXY YYZ) where the tRNAs can re-pair after slipping one nucleotide backward, followed by a downstream stimulatory structure such as an RNA pseudoknot or stem-loop
A premature stop codon that causes the ribosome to slip backward and re-initiate
An internal ribosome entry site (IRES) that recruits a second ribosome in a different reading frame
questions.explanation: Programmed -1 ribosomal frameshifting (PRF) is a translational recoding mechanism used by many RNA viruses (HIV, SARS-CoV-2, retroviruses) and some cellular genes to produce fusion proteins from overlapping reading frames. The mechanism requires two cis-acting mRNA elements: (1) Slippery sequence: A heptanucleotide with the pattern X_XXY_YYZ (where spaces indicate the initial reading frame), commonly UUUAAAC or AAAUUUU. The key requirement is that the P-site and A-site tRNAs can re-pair with the mRNA after slipping back by one nucleotide (from the 0-frame XXY YYZ to the -1-frame XXX YYY). The slippery sequence provides near-cognate base pairing in the -1 frame. (2) Downstream stimulatory structure: An RNA pseudoknot (most common) or stable stem-loop located 5-9 nucleotides downstream of the slippery site. This structure creates a mechanical barrier that pauses the ribosome over the slippery sequence, providing a kinetic window for frameshifting. The pseudoknot resists unwinding by the ribosomal helicase, creating tension that is resolved by the backward slip. The efficiency of frameshifting (typically 5-30%) determines the ratio of the upstream gene product to the fusion protein, which is critical for viral assembly. In HIV, -1 PRF produces the Gag-Pol polyprotein at ~5% efficiency relative to the Gag protein, a ratio essential for proper virion assembly.

questions.question: Post-translational modifications (PTMs) extend the functional diversity of the proteome. Protein glycosylation, one of the most common PTMs, occurs in two main forms. What distinguishes N-linked from O-linked glycosylation?
options: N-linked uses DNA as a sugar template while O-linked uses RNA
N-linked glycosylation occurs on the N-terminus of the protein while O-linked occurs on the C-terminus
Both types attach sugars to the same amino acid residues but use different sugar donors

N-linked glycosylation attaches oligosaccharides to asparagine residues in the Asn-X-Ser/Thr sequon via the amide nitrogen, beginning in the ER with a preassembled 14-sugar core; O-linked glycosylation attaches sugars to serine or threonine hydroxyl groups, mainly in the Golgi
questions.explanation: Protein glycosylation is the most complex post-translational modification, affecting approximately 50% of all eukaryotic proteins. The two main types differ in their chemistry, location, and mechanism: N-linked glycosylation: (1) Sugar attachment: An N-glycosidic bond forms between the amide nitrogen of asparagine (Asn) and the sugar N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc). (2) Consensus sequence: Requires the Asn-X-Ser/Thr sequon (where X is any amino acid except proline). (3) Mechanism: A preassembled 14-sugar oligosaccharide (Glc3Man9GlcNAc2) is transferred en bloc from a dolichol phosphate lipid carrier to the nascent polypeptide in the ER lumen by oligosaccharyltransferase (OST). (4) Processing: The core glycan is trimmed (glucose and mannose residues removed) in the ER and further modified in the Golgi (addition of GlcNAc, galactose, sialic acid, fucose). Glycan trimming in the ER is coupled to protein folding quality control (calnexin/calreticulin cycle). O-linked glycosylation: (1) Sugar attachment: An O-glycosidic bond forms between the hydroxyl group of serine or threonine and N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc, the most common) or other sugars. (2) No consensus sequence: O-glycosylation sites are less predictable. (3) Sugars are added one at a time (not as a preassembled block) by specific glycosyltransferases, primarily in the Golgi apparatus. (4) Common examples include mucin-type O-glycosylation (on mucosal glycoproteins) and O-GlcNAcylation (a dynamic, reversible modification on nuclear/cytoplasmic proteins).

questions.question: The discovery of catalytic RNA (ribozymes) by Thomas Cech and Sidney Altman fundamentally changed our understanding of biological catalysis. Cech discovered self-splicing of the Tetrahymena group I intron. What distinguishes the catalytic mechanism of group I introns from group II introns?
options: Group I introns are found only in prokaryotes while group II introns are eukaryote-specific

Group I introns use an exogenous guanosine nucleotide as the nucleophile for the first transesterification, while group II introns use an internal 2'-OH of an adenosine to form a lariat; both are metalloenzymes requiring Mg2+ ions
Group I introns require protein cofactors while group II introns are truly self-splicing
Group I introns splice via hydrolysis while group II introns use transesterification
questions.explanation: Group I and group II introns are both self-splicing ribozymes, but they use fundamentally different mechanisms for the first transesterification step: Group I introns (discovered by Tom Cech in Tetrahymena rRNA, Nobel Prize 1989): (1) First step: An exogenous guanosine (or GTP/GDP/GMP) binds to a specific G-binding site in the intron structure and its 3'-OH acts as the nucleophile, attacking the 5' splice site phosphodiester bond. This frees the 5' exon while attaching the G to the 5' end of the intron. (2) Second step: The free 3'-OH of the 5' exon attacks the 3' splice site, joining the exons and releasing the linear intron (no lariat formed). (3) The intron folds into a complex tertiary structure with two stacked helical domains (P4-P6 and P3-P9) that create the active site. Group II introns (found in organellar and some bacterial genes): (1) First step: The 2'-OH of a conserved bulged adenosine within the intron (in domain VI) attacks the 5' splice site, forming a 2'-5' branch point and creating a lariat intermediate (same as spliceosomal splicing). (2) Second step: The free 3'-OH of the 5' exon attacks the 3' splice site, joining exons and releasing the intron lariat. Both groups require divalent metal ions (Mg2+) for catalysis through a two-metal-ion mechanism, similar to protein metalloenzymes. Both Cech and Altman shared the 1989 Nobel Prize — Altman for discovering the catalytic RNA component of RNase P.
questions.topic: Group I vs Group II intron mechanisms

questions.question: Protein folding in the cell is assisted by molecular chaperones. The GroEL/GroES chaperonin system in E. coli facilitates folding of proteins that cannot fold spontaneously in the crowded cellular environment. What is the mechanism of GroEL/GroES-assisted folding?
options: The unfolded polypeptide binds inside the GroEL barrel via hydrophobic interactions; GroES caps the barrel and ATP hydrolysis drives conformational changes that create a hydrophilic chamber where the protein can fold in isolation for ~10 seconds before release
GroES provides a template of the correct fold that the protein must match before release
GroEL physically pulls on the polypeptide chain to unfold misfolded regions and guide the correct fold
GroEL acts as a protease that degrades misfolded proteins and allows ribosomal re-synthesis
questions.explanation: The GroEL/GroES chaperonin system (type I chaperonin, also called Hsp60/Hsp10) is essential for folding approximately 10-15% of E. coli proteins, particularly those in the 20-60 kDa range. The mechanism involves an iterative annealing cycle: (1) Substrate capture: The unfolded or misfolded polypeptide binds to hydrophobic patches on the apical domains of the GroEL ring (a barrel-shaped complex of 14 identical 57-kDa subunits arranged as two stacked heptameric rings). The binding is driven by hydrophobic interactions with exposed hydrophobic surfaces on the non-native protein. (2) Encapsulation: ATP (7 molecules) binds to the cis ring, followed by GroES (a single heptameric ring of 10-kDa subunits) capping the GroEL cavity. This triggers a massive conformational change in the apical domains that doubles the chamber volume from ~85,000 A^3 to ~175,000 A^3 and switches the chamber wall from hydrophobic to hydrophilic (polar residues now line the interior). (3) Folding: The substrate is released into this sequestered, hydrophilic environment — essentially an 'Anfinsen cage' — where it can fold without interference from aggregation with other proteins. The protein has approximately 10 seconds to fold. (4) Release: ATP hydrolysis (occurring over ~10 seconds) weakens the GroES interaction. Binding of ATP and a new substrate to the trans ring triggers GroES and substrate release. If the protein has not folded correctly, it can rebind for another round.

questions.question: A researcher uses polysome profiling (sucrose gradient ultracentrifugation) to analyze translation in two conditions. In control cells, she observes a typical polysome profile with peaks for 40S, 60S, 80S monosomes, and polysomes (2-mers through 8-mers). After treating cells with a translation initiation inhibitor, she observes increased 80S monosome peak and dramatic reduction of polysome peaks. After treating with a translation elongation inhibitor, she observes increased polysome peaks and decreased monosome peak. What do these patterns reveal?
options: Both inhibitors should produce identical polysome profiles since they both stop translation
The monosome peak represents non-translating ribosomes in both conditions

Initiation inhibitors cause ribosomes to run off mRNAs without new loading, accumulating as empty 80S couples; elongation inhibitors freeze ribosomes on mRNAs, maintaining polysomes while preventing run-off, resulting in polysome stabilization
Initiation inhibitors cause ribosome degradation while elongation inhibitors cause ribosome aggregation
questions.explanation: Polysome profiling separates ribosome-mRNA complexes by size through sucrose gradient sedimentation. The number of ribosomes on an mRNA reflects the balance between initiation rate and elongation/termination rate. Under normal conditions, mRNAs exist as polysomes with multiple ribosomes at various positions. When a translation initiation inhibitor (e.g., harringtonine, hippuristanol, silvestrol) is added: (1) No new ribosomes can load onto mRNAs. (2) Ribosomes already on mRNAs continue to elongate and terminate normally (run-off). (3) As ribosomes complete translation and fall off, they are not replaced. (4) Polysomes progressively lose ribosomes, shifting the distribution toward monosomes and free subunits. (5) The 80S monosome peak increases because ribosomes accumulate as non-translating 80S couples. When a translation elongation inhibitor (e.g., cycloheximide, emetine) is added: (1) Ribosomes already on mRNAs are frozen in place and cannot complete translation. (2) New ribosomes continue to initiate (initiation is unaffected) and join existing polysomes, increasing polysome size. (3) Polysomes become 'heavier' (more ribosomes per mRNA). (4) The monosome peak decreases as monosomes are recruited to mRNAs. This differential response is widely used diagnostically: polysome collapse indicates an initiation defect, while polysome stabilization indicates an elongation defect.

questions.question: ADAR (Adenosine Deaminase Acting on RNA) enzymes catalyze A-to-I (adenosine-to-inosine) RNA editing in double-stranded RNA regions. Inosine is read as guanosine by the translational machinery. In which biological context is A-to-I editing most prevalent and functionally significant?
options: In the mammalian brain, where editing of glutamate receptor (GluA2) pre-mRNA at the Q/R site converts a glutamine codon to an arginine codon, making the receptor calcium-impermeable; this editing is nearly 100% efficient and essential for normal brain function
In yeast mitochondria as part of the RNA interference pathway
In bacterial mRNAs during the SOS response to increase mutagenesis
In plant chloroplasts, where it corrects defective gene sequences
questions.explanation: A-to-I RNA editing by ADAR enzymes (ADAR1 and ADAR2 in mammals) is most prevalent in the central nervous system and has critical functional consequences: (1) GluA2 Q/R site editing: The most physiologically important editing event occurs in the pre-mRNA of GRIA2 (GluA2 subunit of AMPA-type glutamate receptors). ADAR2 converts an adenosine in the second position of a CAG codon (encoding glutamine, Q) to inosine, making it read as CGG (encoding arginine, R). This single amino acid change in the channel pore region (transmembrane domain 2) makes the receptor channel impermeable to Ca2+ ions. This editing is ~99.9% efficient in normal brain tissue. (2) Functional significance: Unedited GluA2 (with Q at the Q/R site) forms Ca2+-permeable AMPA receptors, which cause excitotoxicity. ADAR2 knockout mice die from seizures due to excessive Ca2+ influx through unedited GluA2 receptors. This lethality is rescued by introducing a pre-edited (R-containing) GluA2 allele, proving the essential nature of this single editing event. (3) ADAR also edits thousands of other sites, most in Alu repeat-containing 3' UTRs and introns, modulating innate immune responses (preventing MDA5 activation by endogenous dsRNA) and affecting microRNA processing and alternative splicing.

questions.question: The signal peptide hypothesis, proposed by Gunter Blobel (Nobel Prize 1999), explains how proteins are targeted to specific cellular compartments. What structural features characterize a typical ER signal peptide?
options: A phosphorylated serine cluster that serves as a docking site for the Sec translocon

A 16-30 amino acid N-terminal sequence with three regions: a positively charged n-region, a central hydrophobic h-region of 7-15 leucine/alanine residues forming an alpha-helix, and a c-region with the signal peptidase cleavage site
A C-terminal sequence of exactly 10 amino acids ending in KDEL
A central proline-rich region that creates a rigid structure recognized by SRP
questions.explanation: ER signal peptides (also called signal sequences or leader sequences) are N-terminal targeting sequences that direct nascent polypeptides to the ER for translocation. Despite low primary sequence conservation, they share three structural regions: (1) n-region: The N-terminal portion (1-5 residues) typically carries a net positive charge (1-2 basic residues like Arg or Lys). This positive charge may interact with the negatively charged phospholipid headgroups of the ER membrane during translocon insertion. (2) h-region (hydrophobic core): The central portion (7-15 residues) consists predominantly of hydrophobic amino acids (Leu, Ala, Val, Ile, Phe) that form an alpha-helix. This is the most critical determinant of signal peptide function — it is recognized and bound by the SRP54 methionine-rich M domain through hydrophobic interactions. The hydrophobic core also facilitates insertion into the Sec61 translocon channel. (3) c-region: The C-terminal portion (3-7 residues) contains the signal peptidase cleavage site. The cleavage follows the '-3, -1 rule' (also called the von Heijne rule): small neutral amino acids (Ala, Gly, Ser) are preferred at positions -1 and -3 relative to the cleavage site. Signal peptidase is an ER membrane-bound endoprotease that cleaves the signal peptide co-translationally after the polypeptide emerges into the ER lumen.

questions.question: Crick's adapter hypothesis predicted that small RNA molecules would serve as intermediaries between the nucleotide sequence of mRNA and the amino acid sequence of proteins. This was confirmed by the discovery of transfer RNA. Which experiment by Chapeville et al. (1962) provided definitive proof that it is the tRNA, not the amino acid, that determines codon recognition?
options: They demonstrated that ribosomes can translate mRNA without tRNA
They showed that free amino acids could bind directly to mRNA codons

They chemically converted cysteine attached to tRNA-Cys into alanine using Raney nickel, creating alanyl-tRNA-Cys; this hybrid aminoacyl-tRNA inserted alanine at positions normally occupied by cysteine, proving the tRNA anticodon determines coding specificity
They proved that aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases read codons on mRNA
questions.explanation: The Chapeville experiment was an elegant demonstration that the tRNA adapter, not the amino acid it carries, determines where an amino acid is inserted during translation. The experiment proceeded as follows: (1) Cysteinyl-tRNA synthetase charged tRNA-Cys with cysteine, creating cysteinyl-tRNA-Cys (normal). (2) The attached cysteine was chemically reduced to alanine using Raney nickel (a desulfurization catalyst). This created a 'misacylated' or hybrid aminoacyl-tRNA: alanyl-tRNA-Cys — tRNA-Cys carrying alanine instead of its cognate cysteine. (3) This hybrid tRNA was used in an in vitro translation system with a synthetic mRNA containing cysteine codons (UGU/UGC). (4) Result: Alanine was incorporated into the protein at positions specified by cysteine codons. This proved that the ribosome reads the tRNA anticodon, not the amino acid. The tRNA-Cys anticodon (GCA) recognized the cysteine codon (UGC) and inserted whatever amino acid was attached — in this case, alanine. This experiment validated Crick's adapter hypothesis and demonstrated that the 'second genetic code' (the aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase recognition of cognate tRNAs) is crucial for maintaining translational fidelity. Any error in tRNA charging would result in amino acid misincorporation because the ribosome has no mechanism to verify the amino acid-anticodon match.

questions.question: A researcher wants to identify all the direct RNA targets of a specific RNA-binding protein (RBP) in living cells. She needs a method that captures only direct protein-RNA contacts and provides nucleotide-level resolution. Which technique should she use?
options: RNA-seq of total cellular RNA to identify all expressed transcripts
Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP-seq) to identify DNA binding sites of the protein
Yeast two-hybrid assay to identify protein-protein interactions of the RBP

CLIP-seq (Cross-Linking and Immunoprecipitation followed by sequencing): UV irradiation creates covalent crosslinks between the RBP and RNA at direct contact sites in vivo, followed by immunoprecipitation and high-throughput sequencing of bound RNA fragments
questions.explanation: CLIP-seq (Cross-Linking and Immunoprecipitation followed by sequencing) and its variants (HITS-CLIP, PAR-CLIP, iCLIP, eCLIP) are the gold standard methods for identifying direct RNA targets of RNA-binding proteins at nucleotide resolution. The basic protocol involves: (1) UV crosslinking: Living cells are irradiated with UV light (254 nm for HITS-CLIP, or 365 nm for PAR-CLIP which uses 4-thiouridine-labeled RNA). UV creates covalent bonds between proteins and RNA at zero-distance contact points (typically within 1-2 Angstroms). This captures only direct interactions. (2) Cell lysis and RNase treatment: Partial RNase digestion trims the RNA to short fragments (~30-50 nt) flanking the crosslink site. (3) Immunoprecipitation: An antibody against the RBP (or an epitope tag) is used to pull down the protein along with covalently attached RNA fragments. Stringent washing removes non-specific associations. (4) RNA isolation: The protein is digested with proteinase K, and the RNA fragments (with a short peptide remnant at the crosslink site) are isolated. (5) Library preparation and sequencing: RNA fragments are converted to a cDNA library and sequenced by high-throughput sequencing. (6) Analysis: Reads are mapped to the transcriptome to identify binding sites. The crosslink site causes reverse transcriptase to stall or introduce mutations, enabling nucleotide-level resolution of the binding site. RNA-seq would show all expressed RNAs but not binding; ChIP-seq is for DNA-binding proteins.

questions.question: Internal ribosome entry sites (IRES) allow cap-independent translation initiation of certain eukaryotic mRNAs. Under which physiological condition is IRES-dependent translation most important?
options: During meiosis when all cap-dependent translation is permanently shut down

During cellular stress (heat shock, apoptosis, hypoxia, viral infection) when cap-dependent translation is inhibited by eIF4E sequestration or eIF2alpha phosphorylation, allowing continued translation of stress-response mRNAs
During DNA replication in S phase when ribosomes are redirected from translation to replication
During normal growth when cap-dependent translation is operating at maximum efficiency
questions.explanation: IRES elements are structured RNA sequences in the 5' UTR that recruit ribosomes directly to internal positions on the mRNA without scanning from the 5' cap. IRES-dependent translation becomes critically important during cellular stress conditions when cap-dependent translation is globally inhibited. The mechanisms include: (1) eIF2alpha phosphorylation: Stress kinases (GCN2, PERK, PKR, HRI) phosphorylate eIF2alpha, reducing the pool of eIF2-GTP-Met-tRNAi ternary complex and globally inhibiting cap-dependent initiation. IRES-containing mRNAs (e.g., ATF4, BiP/GRP78, XIAP) can still be translated because they recruit ribosomes through alternative mechanisms. (2) eIF4E sequestration: During apoptosis, 4E-BP1 is dephosphorylated and sequesters eIF4E, preventing eIF4F complex assembly and cap-dependent scanning. IRES-containing mRNAs encoding anti-apoptotic proteins (XIAP, Bcl-2, Bcl-xL) or pro-apoptotic factors (Apaf-1, DAP5) continue to be translated. (3) Viral hijacking: Viral IRES elements (picornavirus, HCV, cricket paralysis virus) allow viral mRNA translation while host cap-dependent translation is shut down by viral proteases that cleave eIF4G. IRES elements vary in structure and factor requirements — some (like CrPV IRES) can directly recruit 40S subunits without any initiation factors.

questions.question: The Mediator complex is a large multi-subunit coactivator that bridges gene-specific transcription factors and RNA Polymerase II. How does Mediator facilitate activated transcription?
options: Mediator directly methylates histone tails to open chromatin structure
Mediator replaces TFIID at the promoter and provides an alternative TATA-binding mechanism
Mediator functions as an RNA helicase that unwinds mRNA secondary structure during transcription

Mediator transmits activating signals from enhancer-bound transcription factors to the Pol II pre-initiation complex at the promoter, stimulating PIC assembly, Pol II CTD phosphorylation, and promoter escape through conformational changes
questions.explanation: The Mediator complex is a ~1.2 MDa multi-subunit complex (25-30 subunits in yeast, 30+ in humans) that is essential for virtually all Pol II-dependent transcription. It functions as a molecular bridge and signal integrator: (1) Structure: Mediator has a modular architecture with head, middle, tail, and kinase modules. The head and middle modules interact with Pol II and GTFs at the promoter, while the tail module interacts with gene-specific activators bound at enhancers. (2) Basal transcription: Mediator stabilizes the PIC by bridging the Pol II-TFIIF complex with TFIID and TFIIH at the promoter, enhancing PIC assembly rate. (3) Activated transcription: When activator proteins (e.g., p53, NF-kappaB, nuclear receptors) bind to enhancer elements, they recruit Mediator through direct interactions with specific Mediator subunits (e.g., MED1 binds nuclear receptors). This recruitment concentrates Mediator at the promoter, dramatically stimulating PIC formation and Pol II loading. (4) Mediator also stimulates TFIIH-mediated CTD phosphorylation at Ser5, promoting promoter escape and the transition to productive elongation. (5) The kinase module (CDK8/CycC/MED12/MED13) can act as a repressive submodule that must dissociate for full activation. (6) Mediator interacts with the enhancer-promoter loop architecture facilitated by cohesin and CTCF.

questions.question: Sickle cell disease results from a single nucleotide change in the beta-globin gene (GAG to GTG in DNA, or GAG to GUG in mRNA) that converts glutamic acid at position 6 to valine. Why does this specific amino acid substitution cause hemoglobin polymerization under low oxygen conditions?
options: Valine is larger than glutamic acid and sterically prevents normal hemoglobin tetramer formation
Valine at position 6 binds oxygen irreversibly, preventing normal oxygen release in tissues
The mutation eliminates a disulfide bond that normally stabilizes the hemoglobin quaternary structure

The substitution replaces a charged, hydrophilic glutamic acid with a nonpolar, hydrophobic valine that creates a sticky hydrophobic patch on the surface of deoxyhemoglobin, which fits into a complementary hydrophobic pocket on an adjacent hemoglobin molecule, triggering polymerization into long fibers
questions.explanation: The molecular pathology of sickle cell disease illustrates how a single amino acid change can have devastating physiological consequences. In normal hemoglobin (HbA), glutamic acid at position 6 (beta6Glu) is on the surface of the beta-globin chain, where its negative charge and hydrophilicity contribute to hemoglobin solubility. In sickle hemoglobin (HbS), valine replaces glutamic acid (beta6Val). This has minimal effect on oxyhemoglobin conformation or function. However, when hemoglobin releases oxygen (deoxyhemoglobin), a conformational change exposes a hydrophobic pocket near the EF corner of the beta chain. The hydrophobic valine at position 6 on one HbS molecule fits precisely into this hydrophobic pocket on an adjacent HbS molecule, creating an intermolecular contact that does not exist in HbA (because glutamic acid's charge repels it from the hydrophobic pocket). This specific molecular complementarity triggers the assembly of HbS molecules into long, rigid polymer fibers (with 14 strands in a helical arrangement). These fibers distort the red blood cell into the characteristic sickle shape, making cells rigid and prone to hemolysis and vaso-occlusion. Importantly, HbA cannot polymerize because beta6Glu cannot make this hydrophobic contact, explaining why heterozygous carriers (HbAS) are largely protected.

questions.question: A researcher measures the effect of various inhibitors on protein synthesis using a cell-free translation system from rabbit reticulocytes. Cycloheximide completely blocks amino acid incorporation. Puromycin causes rapid release of truncated polypeptide chains. When both are added simultaneously, amino acid incorporation stops immediately. Why do these two translation elongation inhibitors produce different effects?
options: Cycloheximide blocks translocation by binding the E site of the 60S subunit, freezing ribosomes on mRNA without releasing peptides; puromycin structurally mimics aminoacyl-tRNA, enters the A site, forms a peptide bond with the nascent chain, then dissociates because it lacks a stable tRNA structure, releasing premature peptidyl-puromycin
Both inhibitors block the same step but with different kinetics
Cycloheximide degrades mRNA while puromycin degrades tRNA
Cycloheximide is an initiation inhibitor while puromycin affects termination
questions.explanation: Cycloheximide and puromycin are both translation inhibitors but work through completely different mechanisms, making them valuable experimental tools: Cycloheximide: (1) Binds to the E site of the 60S large ribosomal subunit. (2) Blocks translocation — the ribosome cannot move from pre-translocation state (peptidyl-tRNA in A site, deacylated tRNA in P site) to post-translocation state. (3) Ribosomes are frozen on mRNA with intact peptidyl-tRNAs. No peptide chains are released. (4) Specific for eukaryotic 80S ribosomes. Puromycin: (1) Is a structural analog of aminoacyl-tRNA (specifically tyrosyl-tRNA). It has an adenosine moiety linked to a modified amino acid through an amide bond instead of an ester bond. (2) Enters the ribosomal A site and acts as an acceptor in the peptidyl transferase reaction. (3) The nascent peptide chain is transferred to puromycin, forming peptidyl-puromycin. (4) However, the amide bond in puromycin (unlike the ester bond in normal aminoacyl-tRNA) makes the product resistant to hydrolysis, and puromycin lacks the tRNA body needed for translocation. (5) Peptidyl-puromycin dissociates from the ribosome, causing premature chain termination. (6) Affects both prokaryotic and eukaryotic ribosomes. When both drugs are added together, cycloheximide freezes ribosomes immediately, preventing the translocation that would be needed to create empty A sites for puromycin to enter.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about eukaryotic transcription factors and promoter elements:
S1: The TATA box is found in all eukaryotic promoters and is required for transcription of every gene
S2: CpG islands are GC-rich regions near promoters of housekeeping genes and are typically unmethylated in expressing cells
S3: Enhancers can function at distances of hundreds of kilobases from their target promoters and can work in either orientation
S4: The BRE (TFIIB Recognition Element) is directly recognized by RNA Polymerase II without any transcription factors
options: S1-False, S2-True, S3-True, S4-False
S1-True, S2-True, S3-True, S4-False
S1-False, S2-False, S3-True, S4-False
S1-False, S2-True, S3-False, S4-True
questions.explanation: S1 is FALSE: The TATA box (TATAAA consensus, ~25-30 bp upstream of TSS) is found in only about 10-20% of human gene promoters. Most promoters are TATA-less and instead use alternative core promoter elements such as the Inr (Initiator), DPE (Downstream Promoter Element), or are CpG island-associated. TBP is still recruited to TATA-less promoters through TAF-dependent mechanisms or via other TBP-containing complexes. S2 is TRUE: CpG islands are regions of >200 bp with >50% GC content and observed/expected CpG ratio >0.6. They are associated with approximately 70% of human gene promoters, particularly housekeeping genes. In expressing cells, CpG island promoters are unmethylated, maintaining an open chromatin state. Methylation of CpG islands (by DNMT3A/3B) leads to transcriptional silencing and is a mechanism for gene regulation during development and X-inactivation. S3 is TRUE: Enhancers are cis-regulatory elements that can activate transcription from enormous distances (up to >1 Mb in some cases) and function in either orientation relative to the promoter. They work through DNA looping, where the enhancer-bound activator proteins directly contact the Mediator/PIC complex at the promoter. Cohesin and CTCF organize TADs (topologically associating domains) that constrain enhancer-promoter interactions. S4 is FALSE: The BRE is recognized by TFIIB (Transcription Factor IIB), not by RNA Pol II directly. TFIIB recognizes the BRE through its helix-turn-helix motif and bridges between TBP/TFIID and RNA Pol II.

questions.question: Prions represent an extraordinary exception to the central dogma, where a misfolded protein can template the conformational change of normal proteins without any nucleic acid involvement. In yeast, the [PSI+] prion corresponds to a self-propagating aggregated form of which protein, and what is the phenotypic consequence?
options: Rnq1, a prion domain-containing protein; [PSI+] cells have enhanced mRNA splicing efficiency

Sup35, a translation termination factor (eRF3 homolog); [PSI+] cells have reduced translation termination fidelity, leading to increased read-through of stop codons and production of extended proteins
Ure2, a nitrogen catabolism regulator; [PSI+] cells cannot utilize poor nitrogen sources
Hsp104, a protein disaggregase; [PSI+] cells have increased thermotolerance
questions.explanation: The yeast [PSI+] prion is one of the best-characterized prion systems and has provided fundamental insights into protein-based inheritance. [PSI+] is the prion form of Sup35, the yeast eRF3 (eukaryotic Release Factor 3) homolog. Sup35 normally functions in translation termination: (1) Normal function: Sup35/eRF3 works with Sup45/eRF1 to recognize stop codons and terminate translation. Sup35 is a GTPase that enhances the activity of Sup45 at the ribosomal A site. (2) Prion conversion: In [PSI+] cells, Sup35 adopts a self-propagating amyloid conformation where the N-terminal prion domain (NM domain) polymerizes into ordered aggregates (amyloid fibers). This sequesters Sup35 into aggregates, depleting the pool of functional, soluble Sup35. (3) Phenotypic consequence: Reduced functional Sup35 leads to inefficient translation termination, causing ribosomes to read through stop codons at elevated frequency. This produces C-terminally extended proteins. The [PSI+] phenotype was originally detected as a nonsense suppressor — it suppressed nonsense mutations in reporter genes (e.g., ade1-14 UAG mutant), allowing growth on media lacking adenine. (4) Inheritance: [PSI+] is inherited cytoplasmically (non-Mendelian) because aggregated Sup35 seeds are transmitted to daughter cells during cell division. Hsp104 chaperone is required for prion propagation — it fragments large aggregates into smaller seeds that are distributed during cell division.

questions.question: The poly-A tail of eukaryotic mRNA serves multiple functions in mRNA metabolism. What is the molecular mechanism by which the poly-A tail stimulates translation initiation?
options: PABPC1 (cytoplasmic poly-A binding protein) binds the poly-A tail and interacts with eIF4G, which also binds eIF4E at the 5' cap, creating a closed-loop mRNA structure that enhances ribosome recycling and re-initiation
Poly-A tail length determines the number of ribosomes that can bind simultaneously
The poly-A tail base-pairs directly with the 18S rRNA to recruit the 40S subunit
The poly-A tail serves as an internal ribosome entry site for cap-independent translation
questions.explanation: The poly-A tail's role in translation involves the formation of a closed-loop mRNA structure: (1) eIF4E binds the 5' m7G cap structure. (2) eIF4G serves as a scaffolding protein that simultaneously binds eIF4E (via its N-terminal domain), eIF4A (RNA helicase, via its middle domain), and PABPC1 (via its C-terminal domain). (3) PABPC1 (poly-A binding protein, cytoplasmic 1) coats the poly-A tail with multiple copies (each PABPC1 molecule covers ~25 adenosines). The PABPC1 molecules closest to the 3' UTR interact with eIF4G. (4) These simultaneous interactions circularize the mRNA, bringing the 3' and 5' ends into proximity. This closed-loop structure (visualized by electron microscopy and atomic force microscopy) enhances translation through: (a) Promoting ribosome recycling — ribosomes that terminate at the stop codon are in proximity to the 5' cap and can re-initiate on the same mRNA efficiently. (b) Ensuring that only intact, fully processed mRNAs (those with both a cap and a poly-A tail) are efficiently translated. (c) Stimulating 60S subunit joining during initiation. (d) Synergistic stimulation — the cap and poly-A tail enhance translation more than either alone (multiplicative effect). Deadenylation (shortening of the poly-A tail) is typically the first and rate-limiting step in mRNA decay, disrupting the closed loop and making the mRNA accessible to decapping enzymes.

questions.question: Protein targeting to mitochondria requires the TOM/TIM translocase complexes. Most mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear genes and synthesized on cytoplasmic ribosomes. What structural feature of these proteins directs them to mitochondria?
options: A GPI anchor that targets proteins to the mitochondrial intermembrane space
A lipid modification (myristoylation) that inserts directly into the mitochondrial outer membrane
A C-terminal KDEL sequence that redirects ER-targeted proteins to mitochondria

An N-terminal presequence of 20-40 amino acids that forms an amphipathic alpha-helix with positively charged residues on one face, recognized by Tom20/Tom22 receptors on the outer mitochondrial membrane
questions.explanation: The mitochondrial targeting signal (MTS), also called the presequence or transit peptide, is distinct from the ER signal peptide. Key features: (1) Structure: The MTS is an N-terminal extension of 20-40 amino acids that forms an amphipathic alpha-helix. One face of the helix displays positively charged residues (Arg, Lys — typically no Asp or Glu), while the opposite face is hydrophobic. This amphipathic character is the defining feature, rather than any specific consensus sequence. (2) Recognition: Tom20 receptor on the outer membrane recognizes the hydrophobic face of the amphipathic helix, while Tom22 recognizes the positively charged face. (3) Import pathway: The preprotein passes through the TOM complex (Translocase of the Outer Membrane) pore (Tom40 channel), then through the TIM23 complex (Translocase of the Inner Membrane) to reach the matrix. The membrane potential (negative inside) across the inner membrane drives electrophoretic translocation of the positively charged presequence. The mitochondrial Hsp70 (mtHsp70/mortalin) in the matrix pulls the protein through via the 'import motor' mechanism. (4) Processing: After import, the matrix processing peptidase (MPP) cleaves the presequence, releasing the mature protein. Some proteins undergo a second cleavage by MIP (mitochondrial intermediate peptidase). (5) Proteins destined for the outer membrane, intermembrane space, or inner membrane use alternative signals and pathways (SAM, MIA, TIM22 complexes).

questions.question: The concept of molecular chaperones was established when it was realized that many proteins require assistance to fold correctly in the cellular environment. Hsp70 chaperones (DnaK in E. coli) represent the most ubiquitous chaperone family. What is the ATP-dependent cycle of Hsp70 that assists protein folding?
options: ATP binding permanently locks the substrate in the Hsp70 binding cleft until folding is complete
Hsp70 transfers ATP energy directly to the unfolded polypeptide to drive the folding reaction
Hsp70 uses ATP to physically unfold misfolded proteins by pulling on exposed hydrophobic segments

ATP-bound Hsp70 has an open lid and low substrate affinity, allowing rapid binding/release of unfolded segments; ATP hydrolysis (stimulated by co-chaperone Hsp40/DnaJ) closes the lid, trapping the substrate; nucleotide exchange factor (GrpE/BAG) exchanges ADP for ATP, reopening the lid for substrate release
questions.explanation: The Hsp70 chaperone system operates through an iterative ATP-driven cycle of substrate binding and release: (1) ATP-bound state (open): Hsp70 in the ATP-bound conformation has its substrate-binding domain lid in an open position, with low affinity and high exchange rates for substrates. This allows rapid sampling of unfolded or partially folded polypeptide segments. (2) Substrate recognition: Hsp70 recognizes short hydrophobic peptide segments (~7 residues enriched in Leu, Ile, Val, Phe) that are normally buried in the protein interior but are exposed in non-native conformations. The co-chaperone Hsp40 (DnaJ in E. coli) delivers substrates to Hsp70 and contains a J-domain that stimulates Hsp70's intrinsic ATPase activity. (3) ATP hydrolysis (closed): J-domain-stimulated ATP hydrolysis triggers a conformational change that closes the alpha-helical lid over the substrate-binding cleft, trapping the substrate with high affinity and low exchange rate. This prevents aggregation and may locally unfold misfolded segments. (4) Substrate release: A nucleotide exchange factor (GrpE in bacteria, BAG-family proteins or Hsp110 in eukaryotes) promotes ADP release and ATP rebinding, which opens the lid and releases the substrate. (5) The released substrate can attempt to fold. If it folds correctly, it escapes the cycle. If not, exposed hydrophobic segments will be recaptured by Hsp70 for another round. Multiple cycles may be needed for complex proteins.

questions.question: A molecular biology class performs an experiment where they treat E. coli with rifampicin (an RNA polymerase inhibitor) and simultaneously add 35S-methionine. They observe that protein synthesis continues for approximately 3-5 minutes after rifampicin addition, then stops. When they repeat the experiment in eukaryotic cells (using actinomycin D as the transcription inhibitor), protein synthesis continues for hours. What accounts for this dramatic difference?
options: Eukaryotic cells store pre-made mRNAs in the nucleus that are gradually released

Bacterial mRNAs have very short half-lives (2-5 minutes) due to rapid degradation by RNase E and other endoribonucleases, while eukaryotic mRNAs are stabilized by the 5' cap and poly-A tail, with half-lives ranging from 30 minutes to days
Bacteria have fewer ribosomes than eukaryotic cells
Rifampicin inhibits translation in addition to transcription
questions.explanation: This experiment reveals a fundamental difference in mRNA stability between prokaryotes and eukaryotes: Bacterial mRNA stability: (1) Average half-life is only 2-5 minutes in E. coli. (2) mRNA degradation begins while the message is still being transcribed and translated (co-transcriptional degradation). (3) The primary degradation pathway involves: RNase E (endonucleolytic cleavage at AU-rich single-stranded regions) → PNPase and RNase II (3'-to-5' exonucleolytic degradation of fragments). (4) The absence of a 5' cap leaves mRNAs vulnerable to 5'-end-dependent degradation (RNase E prefers 5'-monophosphate substrates; RppH pyrophosphohydrolase removes the 5' triphosphate). (5) After rifampicin stops new transcription, existing mRNAs are rapidly degraded, and protein synthesis ceases within minutes. Eukaryotic mRNA stability: (1) Average half-life ranges from 30 minutes to >24 hours (some are >10 hours). (2) The 5' m7G cap protects against 5'-to-3' exonucleases (Xrn1). (3) The poly-A tail (with bound PABPC1) protects against 3'-to-5' exonucleases (exosome). (4) The closed-loop structure further stabilizes the mRNA. (5) Degradation requires active deadenylation (CCR4-NOT, PAN2-PAN3 complexes), followed by decapping (DCP1/DCP2), then exonucleolytic decay. (6) After transcription inhibition, the large pool of stable mRNAs supports translation for hours. This difference reflects the distinct regulatory strategies: bacteria use rapid mRNA turnover for quick response to environmental changes, while eukaryotes use mRNA stability regulation as an additional layer of gene expression control.

questions.question: Ribosomal RNA genes are among the most highly transcribed genes in the cell. In eukaryotes, rRNA genes are organized in tandem repeats and transcribed by RNA Pol I to produce a large 45S precursor. What enzyme processes the 45S pre-rRNA into mature 18S, 5.8S, and 28S rRNAs?
options: A single endonuclease (RNase III) that makes all the processing cuts simultaneously
Spliceosomal snRNPs that splice out spacer sequences between the mature rRNAs
A series of endo- and exo-ribonucleases guided by small nucleolar RNAs (snoRNAs) that base-pair with specific sites on the pre-rRNA to direct cleavage, pseudouridylation, and 2'-O-methylation
The ribosomal proteins themselves, which have intrinsic RNase activity
questions.explanation: rRNA processing is a complex, multi-step pathway that converts the 45S/47S pre-rRNA (13.7 kb in humans) into mature 18S (small subunit), 5.8S, and 28S (large subunit) rRNAs. The processing involves: (1) Endonucleolytic cleavages: Multiple endo-ribonuclease cleavages separate the mature rRNA sequences from the external transcribed spacers (5' ETS, 3' ETS) and internal transcribed spacers (ITS1, ITS2). Key endonucleases include: RNase III family members (Rnt1 in yeast), the PIN-domain endoribonuclease Utp24, and others. The order of cleavages varies between organisms. (2) Exonucleolytic trimming: After endonucleolytic cleavage, 5'-to-3' exonucleases (Rat1/Xrn2, Rrp17) and 3'-to-5' exonucleases (the nuclear exosome complex) trim the pre-rRNA intermediates to their final lengths. (3) Guide snoRNAs: Two main classes of small nucleolar RNAs direct covalent modifications: Box C/D snoRNAs guide 2'-O-methylation (~100 sites in human rRNA) by base-pairing with the target site and recruiting the methyltransferase fibrillarin. Box H/ACA snoRNAs guide pseudouridylation (~100 sites) by recruiting dyskerin. (4) Some snoRNAs (U3, U14, snR30/U17) are essential for endonucleolytic cleavages. (5) The processing occurs in the nucleolus and is coupled with ribosomal protein assembly.

questions.question: Bacterial sigma factors provide promoter specificity to RNA polymerase. Under stress conditions, alternative sigma factors compete with the primary sigma-70 for binding to core RNA polymerase. How does the sigma-32 (RpoH) heat shock sigma factor enable a rapid transcriptional response to elevated temperature?
options: At normal temperature, sigma-32 mRNA is translationally repressed by secondary structure that sequesters the ribosome binding site; heat shock melts this structure, enabling rapid sigma-32 translation without requiring new transcription; additionally, DnaK normally targets sigma-32 for FtsH protease degradation, but at high temperature DnaK is titrated away by misfolded proteins
Sigma-32 is constitutively active but is only needed when sigma-70 spontaneously denatures at high temperature
Sigma-32 is imported from outside the cell through heat-activated membrane channels
Heat shock causes sigma-70 to be degraded, leaving sigma-32 as the only available sigma factor
questions.explanation: The regulation of sigma-32 (heat shock sigma factor) in E. coli illustrates multiple layers of rapid post-transcriptional regulation: (1) Translational regulation: At normal temperature (30-37C), the sigma-32 mRNA (rpoH) forms a stable secondary structure that occludes the Shine-Dalgarno sequence and AUG start codon, preventing ribosome binding. When temperature increases, this RNA thermometer structure melts, immediately allowing ribosome access and rapid sigma-32 translation. This is the fastest response mechanism because it uses pre-existing mRNA. (2) Protein stability regulation: Even when sigma-32 protein is produced at normal temperature, it is rapidly degraded (half-life ~1 minute). The DnaK (Hsp70) chaperone, along with DnaJ and GrpE, binds sigma-32 and delivers it to the FtsH (HflB) membrane protease for degradation. At elevated temperatures, misfolded proteins accumulate and titrate away the DnaK/DnaJ chaperones (which preferentially bind to misfolded clients), freeing sigma-32 from degradation. This increases sigma-32 levels. (3) Competitive binding: Increased sigma-32 competes with sigma-70 for binding to core RNA polymerase. Sigma-32-holoenzyme recognizes heat shock promoters (with different -10 and -35 consensus sequences) and transcribes heat shock genes (groEL, groES, dnaK, dnaJ, clpB, etc.). (4) Homeostatic feedback: As chaperone levels increase, DnaK again targets sigma-32 for degradation, returning the system to basal levels.

questions.question: The genetic code was deciphered through multiple experimental approaches. Khorana's contribution involved synthesizing mRNA with known repeating sequences. When he used a repeating dinucleotide poly(UC), the cell-free translation system produced a polypeptide with alternating amino acids. What were these alternating amino acids, and why does a repeating dinucleotide produce alternating rather than homopolymeric amino acids?
options: Poly(UC) produces alternating phenylalanine and proline because UC is read as two separate codons
Poly(UC) produces a random mixture of all amino acids because the ribosome cannot maintain reading frame
Poly(UC) produces only serine because UCU is read repeatedly from a fixed starting point
Poly(UC) produces alternating serine (UCU) and leucine (CUC) because the reading frame cycles between two codons: ...UCU CUC UCU CUC..., giving a poly(Ser-Leu) dipeptide repeat
questions.explanation: Har Gobind Khorana's elegant contribution to genetic code decipherment (Nobel Prize 1968, shared with Nirenberg and Holley) used synthetic mRNAs with defined repeating sequences. For a repeating dinucleotide poly(UC): ...UCUCUCUCUCUCUC..., the reading frame determines which codons are generated. Since there is no defined start codon in these in vitro experiments, ribosomes can initiate in any of three possible reading frames: Frame 1: UCU-CUC-UCU-CUC... → Ser-Leu-Ser-Leu... Frame 2: CUC-UCU-CUC-UCU... → Leu-Ser-Leu-Ser... Frame 3: (requires starting mid-codon, producing the same alternation). Regardless of the starting frame, the protein product is a repeating dipeptide of serine and leucine. This is because a repeating dinucleotide creates a pattern where two different codons alternate. In contrast, a repeating trinucleotide (e.g., poly(UCU) = ...UCUUCUUCUUCU...) would produce three different homopolymers depending on reading frame: poly(Ser) from UCU, poly(Ser) from UUC... wait — actually poly(UUC) = Phe, and poly(CUU) = Leu. This approach systematically assigned codons to amino acids when combined with the known amino acid compositions of the resulting polypeptides.

questions.question: A graduate student wants to determine the precise 5' end of an mRNA transcript in order to map the transcription start site (TSS). Which technique would provide single-nucleotide resolution mapping of the TSS?
options: Primer extension analysis: hybridize a radiolabeled DNA primer complementary to a known downstream sequence of the mRNA, extend with reverse transcriptase, and determine the product length by gel electrophoresis alongside a sequencing ladder
Western blot of the protein product to infer mRNA properties
RNA-seq with standard library preparation to count total reads
Northern blot analysis to determine the total mRNA length
questions.explanation: Primer extension is a classic technique for mapping transcription start sites with single-nucleotide resolution. The procedure involves: (1) Design a short DNA primer (typically 20-25 nt) complementary to a known sequence within the first 100-200 nucleotides of the mRNA (downstream of the expected TSS). (2) Radiolabel the primer at its 5' end with 32P using T4 polynucleotide kinase. (3) Hybridize the labeled primer to total cellular RNA or poly(A)+ mRNA under denaturing/reannealing conditions. (4) Extend the primer using reverse transcriptase (e.g., AMV-RT or SuperScript), which synthesizes cDNA complementary to the mRNA, extending from the primer to the 5' end of the mRNA. (5) When reverse transcriptase reaches the 5' cap, it stops (or falls off), producing a cDNA product whose length corresponds to the distance from the primer to the 5' end. (6) Resolve the extension product on a denaturing polyacrylamide gel alongside a DNA sequencing ladder (generated using the same primer on a cloned genomic DNA template). The size of the primer extension product directly indicates the position of the TSS. Alternative methods include S1 nuclease mapping (using DNA probes) and, more modernly, CAGE (Cap Analysis of Gene Expression) or TSS-seq for genome-wide TSS mapping at nucleotide resolution.

questions.question: Eukaryotic mRNA decay typically begins with deadenylation. The two major cytoplasmic mRNA decay pathways that follow deadenylation are the 5'-to-3' and 3'-to-5' pathways. What are the key enzymes in each pathway?
options: The 5'-to-3' pathway uses poly-A polymerase in reverse, and the 3'-to-5' pathway uses the spliceosome
RNase H cleaves both pathways after forming DNA-RNA hybrids with small RNAs
Both pathways use the same endonuclease that cleaves the mRNA in the middle

In the 5'-to-3' pathway, Dcp1/Dcp2 remove the 5' cap (decapping) and Xrn1 degrades the body 5'-to-3'; in the 3'-to-5' pathway, the cytoplasmic exosome complex degrades the body 3'-to-5', and DcpS hydrolyzes the remaining cap structure
questions.explanation: After deadenylation (catalyzed primarily by the CCR4-NOT complex and PAN2-PAN3), the mRNA body can be degraded by two convergent pathways: 5'-to-3' decay pathway: (1) Decapping: Once the poly-A tail is shortened below ~10-12 adenines, the mRNA loses PABPC1 protection and becomes a substrate for decapping. The decapping enzyme Dcp2 (with activator Dcp1) catalyzes hydrolysis of the m7GpppN cap, releasing m7GDP and a 5'-monophosphorylated mRNA. (2) Decapping enhancers (Pat1, Lsm1-7 ring complex, Dhh1/DDX6 helicase, Edc1-4) promote decapping. (3) The 5'-monophosphate is then recognized by Xrn1, a highly processive 5'-to-3' exoribonuclease that rapidly degrades the entire mRNA body. (4) This pathway is concentrated in cytoplasmic processing bodies (P-bodies), which are membrane-less organelles enriched in decay factors. 3'-to-5' decay pathway: (1) The cytoplasmic exosome (a ring-shaped complex of 9 structural subunits with associated catalytic subunits Rrp44/Dis3 and Rrp6) degrades the mRNA body in the 3'-to-5' direction. (2) The SKI complex (Ski2 helicase, Ski3, Ski8) threads the mRNA into the exosome channel. (3) After the body is degraded, the remaining 5' cap structure (m7GpppN oligonucleotide) is hydrolyzed by the scavenger decapping enzyme DcpS. Both pathways likely operate simultaneously in vivo, with relative contributions varying by transcript and cell type.

questions.question: The unfolded protein response (UPR) is activated when misfolded proteins accumulate in the endoplasmic reticulum. In mammals, three ER transmembrane sensors activate distinct signaling branches. Which sensor directly acts as both an endoribonuclease and a kinase to initiate its signaling branch?
options: IRE1 (Inositol-Requiring Enzyme 1), which autophosphorylates through its kinase domain and uses its endoribonuclease domain to splice XBP1 mRNA in an unconventional cytoplasmic splicing event, producing the active XBP1s transcription factor
BiP/GRP78, which directly activates all three UPR branches simultaneously
PERK, which phosphorylates eIF2alpha to globally reduce translation
ATF6, which translocates to the Golgi for proteolytic cleavage
questions.explanation: The mammalian UPR has three signaling branches, each initiated by a distinct ER transmembrane sensor. IRE1alpha is unique in possessing both kinase and endoribonuclease activities in its cytoplasmic domain: (1) Sensing: Under normal conditions, BiP/GRP78 chaperone binds to IRE1's luminal domain, keeping it inactive. When misfolded proteins accumulate, BiP dissociates to assist folding, allowing IRE1 to oligomerize. Direct binding of misfolded proteins to IRE1's luminal domain may also promote oligomerization. (2) Activation: Oligomerization triggers trans-autophosphorylation of the kinase domain, which activates the adjacent RNase domain. (3) XBP1 splicing: The activated RNase domain catalyzes unconventional cytoplasmic splicing of XBP1 mRNA, removing a 26-nucleotide intron. This is NOT spliceosomal splicing — IRE1 makes two endonucleolytic cuts, and tRNA ligase joins the exons. The spliced mRNA (XBP1s) encodes an active transcription factor that upregulates ER chaperones, ERAD components, and lipid biosynthesis genes. (4) RIDD: Under prolonged stress, IRE1's RNase also degrades ER-localized mRNAs (Regulated IRE1-Dependent Decay), reducing the folding load. The other branches: PERK phosphorylates eIF2alpha (reducing global translation but paradoxically increasing ATF4 translation), and ATF6 undergoes regulated intramembrane proteolysis (S1P/S2P cleavage in the Golgi) to release an active transcription factor fragment.

questions.question: Bacterial operons allow coordinated expression of functionally related genes from a single polycistronic mRNA. In some operons, the intercistronic regions between cistrons can affect translation efficiency of downstream genes. What structural mechanism in polycistronic mRNAs can cause translational coupling between adjacent cistrons?
options: Ribosomes physically push downstream ribosomes along the mRNA in a processive manner
Each cistron is independently translated from its own cap structure
A single initiator tRNA is used to translate all cistrons sequentially without dissociation

The stop codon of the upstream ORF overlaps with or is immediately adjacent to the Shine-Dalgarno sequence/start codon of the downstream ORF; a ribosome that has just terminated must reinitiate at the downstream start codon, and secondary structures that are unwound by the translating ribosome would otherwise occlude the downstream RBS
questions.explanation: Translational coupling in bacterial polycistronic mRNAs is a regulatory mechanism where translation of a downstream gene depends on active translation of the upstream gene. The molecular mechanism involves overlapping translational signals: (1) Overlapping stop-start signals: In many coupled operons, the stop codon of gene 1 overlaps with the start codon of gene 2 (e.g., the UGAUG sequence contains both TGA stop and AUG start). A terminating ribosome is positioned to reinitiate immediately at the downstream start codon. (2) RNA structure masking: The Shine-Dalgarno sequence and/or start codon of the downstream gene is sequestered in RNA secondary structure (stem-loop) that prevents independent ribosome binding. When a ribosome translates through the upstream gene, it unwinds this structure as it moves through the intercistronic region, transiently exposing the downstream RBS for ribosome loading. If the upstream gene is not translated, the structure re-forms and the downstream gene remains translationally silent. (3) This mechanism ensures stoichiometric production of proteins encoded by adjacent genes, which is important when the proteins function as a complex (e.g., ribosomal protein operons). The coupling ratio can be modulated by the stability of the occluding structure, the distance between the stop and start codons, and the strength of the downstream SD sequence when exposed.

questions.question: The discovery that RNA can catalyze chemical reactions (ribozymes) strongly supports the RNA world hypothesis. Besides the ribosome, which cellular ribozyme was identified by Sidney Altman and contributed to his Nobel Prize?
options: RNase P, which processes the 5' leader sequence of pre-tRNAs; the RNA component alone can catalyze the endonucleolytic cleavage in vitro, while the protein component enhances activity under physiological conditions
The spliceosome, which removes introns from pre-mRNA
Dicer, which cleaves double-stranded RNA into siRNAs
Telomerase, which extends chromosome ends using an RNA template
questions.explanation: Sidney Altman's discovery of the catalytic RNA component of RNase P earned him the 1989 Nobel Prize in Chemistry (shared with Thomas Cech). RNase P is a ribonucleoprotein enzyme found in all domains of life that processes the 5' end of pre-tRNAs: (1) Function: RNase P is an endonuclease that cleaves the 5' leader sequence from precursor tRNAs, generating the mature 5' end. This is an essential processing step for tRNA maturation. (2) Catalytic RNA: In bacteria, RNase P consists of a large RNA subunit (M1 RNA, ~400 nt in E. coli) and a small protein subunit (C5 protein, ~14 kDa). Altman's key finding was that the M1 RNA component ALONE could catalyze the pre-tRNA cleavage reaction in vitro at high salt concentrations, without the protein. (3) Mechanism: The RNA catalyzes hydrolysis of a specific phosphodiester bond, producing a 5'-phosphate on the mature tRNA and a 3'-hydroxyl on the released leader. Two divalent metal ions (Mg2+) are essential for catalysis. (4) The protein subunit enhances the reaction under physiological ionic strength conditions by stabilizing the RNA structure and improving substrate binding. (5) In eukaryotes, RNase P has more protein subunits (9-10 proteins in yeast/humans), but the RNA component retains structural homology. Interestingly, some plant organellar and human mitochondrial RNase P enzymes are protein-only, representing convergent evolution of this essential function.

questions.question: Researchers conduct a reporter gene assay where they fuse the 5' UTR of different mRNAs to a luciferase coding sequence. mRNA-A has a short, unstructured 5' UTR (50 nt) and produces high luciferase activity. mRNA-B has a long 5' UTR (500 nt) with extensive secondary structure and produces low luciferase activity. When eIF4A helicase activity is enhanced by overexpression, mRNA-B translation increases 10-fold while mRNA-A is barely affected. What does this reveal about the role of eIF4A?
options: eIF4A functions as a translation termination factor that is sequestered by 5' UTR structures
eIF4A promotes poly-A tail elongation, which is more important for structured mRNAs
eIF4A stabilizes the mRNA cap structure, and structured 5' UTRs are more prone to decapping

eIF4A is an RNA helicase that unwinds secondary structures in the 5' UTR during ribosome scanning; mRNAs with structured 5' UTRs are dependent on eIF4A helicase activity for efficient scanning, while mRNAs with simple 5' UTRs scan efficiently without helicase assistance
questions.explanation: This reporter assay demonstrates the critical role of eIF4A (a DEAD-box RNA helicase) in cap-dependent translation initiation. eIF4A is the enzymatic subunit of the eIF4F cap-binding complex (eIF4E + eIF4G + eIF4A). During scanning: (1) After the 43S pre-initiation complex is recruited to the 5' cap, it must scan along the 5' UTR in a 5'-to-3' direction to find the AUG start codon. (2) The 40S subunit cannot traverse stable RNA secondary structures (stem-loops, pseudoknots) on its own. (3) eIF4A, powered by ATP hydrolysis, unwinds these structures ahead of the scanning ribosome. eIF4A activity is enhanced by eIF4B and eIF4H cofactors. (4) For mRNA-A with a short, unstructured 5' UTR, scanning is efficient even with basal eIF4A levels because there are no barriers. Additional eIF4A provides minimal benefit. (5) For mRNA-B with extensive secondary structure, scanning is severely impeded. Increasing eIF4A activity removes more structural barriers, dramatically improving scanning efficiency and translation output. This principle has important implications: (a) oncogene mRNAs often have long, structured 5' UTRs and are hypersensitive to eIF4A inhibition (making eIF4A a cancer drug target). (b) Hippuristanol and silvestrol are natural products that inhibit eIF4A and preferentially reduce translation of structured mRNAs.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about bacterial vs eukaryotic transcription:
S1: Bacterial RNA polymerase is a single enzyme that transcribes all types of RNA (mRNA, tRNA, rRNA), while eukaryotes use three specialized RNA polymerases
S2: Bacterial promoters use sigma factors for recognition while eukaryotic Pol II promoters use general transcription factors (GTFs)
S3: Bacterial transcription and translation occur simultaneously in the same compartment
S4: Eukaryotic pre-mRNAs require no processing before translation; they are translated directly as primary transcripts
options: S1-True, S2-True, S3-True, S4-False
S1-True, S2-True, S3-True, S4-True
S1-True, S2-True, S3-False, S4-False
S1-False, S2-True, S3-True, S4-False
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: E. coli has a single core RNA polymerase (alpha2-beta-beta'-omega) that transcribes all genes. Different sigma factors provide promoter specificity but the core enzyme is shared. Eukaryotes have three nuclear RNA polymerases: Pol I (rRNA genes), Pol II (mRNA, most snRNAs), and Pol III (tRNA, 5S rRNA, U6). Some organelles have additional polymerases. S2 is TRUE: In bacteria, the sigma subunit of the holoenzyme directly recognizes promoter sequences (-10 and -35 elements for sigma-70). In eukaryotes, Pol II cannot recognize promoters on its own and requires general transcription factors: TFIID (with TBP) recognizes the TATA box, followed by ordered assembly of TFIIA, TFIIB, Pol II-TFIIF, TFIIE, and TFIIH. S3 is TRUE: Because bacteria lack a nucleus, transcription and translation occur in the same cytoplasmic compartment. Ribosomes begin translating the 5' end of mRNA while RNA polymerase is still transcribing the 3' end. This coupling has important regulatory consequences (attenuation, protection against Rho termination). S4 is FALSE: Eukaryotic pre-mRNAs undergo extensive processing before translation: (1) 5' capping (m7GpppN), (2) splicing (intron removal by the spliceosome), and (3) 3' cleavage and polyadenylation. Only fully processed, mature mRNAs are exported from the nucleus and translated in the cytoplasm.

questions.question: During co-translational protein translocation into the ER, the Sec61 translocon forms a protein-conducting channel. For soluble secretory proteins, the signal peptide opens the lateral gate of Sec61. What determines whether a transmembrane domain is inserted into the lipid bilayer versus being translocated through the channel into the lumen?
options: The hydrophobicity of the segment: sufficiently hydrophobic alpha-helical segments (~20 amino acids) partition laterally through the open gate of Sec61 into the lipid bilayer, while hydrophilic segments pass through the aqueous channel into the lumen
The length of the polypeptide chain determines insertion vs translocation
All segments are initially translocated into the lumen, then hydrophobic ones are pulled back into the membrane
Specific receptor proteins on the cytoplasmic face of the ER select which segments become transmembrane
