(3) Inteins are found in all domains of life and are often embedded in essential, conserved proteins (DNA polymerases, ATPases, ribonucleotide reductases). (4) Split inteins (where the intein is divided between two separate genes) mediate protein trans-splicing, which has been exploited for protein engineering, conditional protein activation, and protein ligation technologies.

questions.question: A researcher uses CRISPR-Cas9 to delete a 200 bp conserved sequence in the 3' UTR of a target mRNA. After deletion, she measures mRNA half-life by actinomycin D chase and finds it increases from 2 hours to 8 hours. The steady-state mRNA level increases 3-fold, but surprisingly, the protein level increases only 1.5-fold. What explains the disproportionate relationship between mRNA and protein level changes?
options: The cell compensates by increasing protein degradation to maintain homeostasis
The protein has an inherent maximum production rate that cannot be exceeded regardless of mRNA levels

The deleted 3' UTR element likely contained both destabilizing elements (such as AU-rich elements that recruit deadenylases) and translational enhancer elements (such as miRNA target sites that paradoxically enhanced translation or structures that promoted ribosome recycling); removing the destabilizing element increased mRNA levels, but simultaneously removing the translational enhancer reduced translational efficiency per mRNA molecule
CRISPR off-target effects reduce global translation efficiency
questions.explanation: The disproportionate relationship between mRNA level changes and protein output changes is a common observation that reveals the complexity of 3' UTR regulatory elements. Several mechanisms can explain this: (1) Dual-function elements: Many 3' UTR sequences contain overlapping or interleaved regulatory elements. The deleted 200 bp region likely contained: (a) Destabilizing elements (e.g., AU-rich elements/AREs bound by TTP/BRF1 that recruit CCR4-NOT deadenylase) — their removal stabilizes the mRNA (half-life 2h → 8h). (b) Translational regulatory elements — binding sites for RNA-binding proteins that enhance translation or optimize mRNA circularization. Removing these reduces translational efficiency (ribosome density per mRNA). (2) miRNA target sites: Some miRNA-mRNA interactions can have paradoxical effects. While miRNAs typically repress translation and destabilize mRNA, removing miRNA sites from the 3' UTR can also disrupt mRNA localization or optimal mRNP composition needed for efficient translation. (3) Structural elements: The deleted sequence may have contained structures important for poly-A tail interaction, closed-loop formation, or polysome stability. (4) Quantitative relationship: If mRNA level increases 3-fold but protein increases only 1.5-fold, the translational efficiency (TE = protein output / mRNA level) decreased by ~50%. This demonstrates that post-transcriptional regulation involves multiple, sometimes opposing, mechanisms encoded in the 3' UTR, and perturbing one element can have complex effects on overall gene expression.

questions.question: Anticodon-codon interactions involve not only Watson-Crick base pairing at positions 1 and 2, but also the wobble position (position 3). In bacteria, the modification of the wobble base (position 34) of the anticodon with queuosine (Q) or its derivatives is widespread. What is the functional significance of queuosine modification?
options: Queuosine prevents aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase from charging the tRNA
Queuosine modification marks tRNAs for degradation when they become uncharged

Queuosine replaces guanosine at position 34 in tRNAs for Asp, Asn, His, and Tyr and restricts wobble pairing to U and C (excluding A) in the third codon position, improving translational accuracy by preventing misreading of non-cognate codons
Queuosine universally enhances wobble flexibility, allowing recognition of all four bases at position 3
questions.explanation: Queuosine (Q) is a hypermodified guanosine found at the wobble position (position 34) of tRNAs decoding NAU and NAC codons (where N is any nucleotide) — specifically tRNAs for Asp (GUC), Asn (AAU/C), His (CAU/C), and Tyr (UAU/C). The modification has several functional consequences: (1) Restricted wobble pairing: Unmodified G at position 34 can wobble-pair with U and C at codon position 3 (and sometimes misread A). Queuosine modification restricts base pairing preferences, improving discrimination between cognate codons (ending in U or C) and near-cognate codons (ending in A or G). This enhances translational fidelity. (2) Translational efficiency: Q-modified tRNAs show altered kinetics in decoding their cognate codons, potentially fine-tuning translation speed at specific codons. (3) Regulation: Queuosine is not synthesized by eukaryotes — it must be obtained from the diet or gut microbiome (as the free base queuine). Bacteria synthesize it de novo. The Q modification status of tRNAs can therefore be influenced by the nutritional state and microbiome, creating a potential link between metabolism and translational regulation. (4) Disease associations: Altered Q modification levels have been observed in cancer cells and are being investigated as potential biomarkers. (5) The tRNA guanine transglycosylase (TGT) enzyme catalyzes the exchange of guanine for queuine base at position 34.

questions.question: During co-translational folding, the ribosomal exit tunnel (approximately 80-100 Angstroms long) can accommodate ~30 amino acids in an extended conformation. Recent research has shown that the tunnel is not merely a passive conduit. What active role does the ribosomal exit tunnel play in protein biogenesis?
options: The tunnel applies mechanical force to unfold any secondary structure in the nascent chain
The tunnel is too narrow for any protein folding to occur inside it
The tunnel catalyzes disulfide bond formation between cysteine residues of the nascent chain

The tunnel has specific constriction points (formed by ribosomal proteins uL4 and uL22) that can sense nascent chain sequences and modulate translation speed; certain peptide sequences (arrest peptides like SecM, MifM) interact with tunnel walls to stall translation, creating regulatory switches
questions.explanation: The ribosomal exit tunnel has been reconceptualized from a passive conduit to an active participant in protein biogenesis and gene regulation. Key features and functions: (1) Tunnel architecture: The tunnel spans ~80-100 Angstroms from the peptidyl transferase center (PTC) to the exit port. It has a variable diameter of 10-20 Angstroms, with a major constriction point ~30 Angstroms from the PTC formed by loops of ribosomal proteins uL4 and uL22 (narrowing to ~10 Angstroms). (2) Arrest peptides: Specific nascent chain sequences interact with the tunnel walls to stall the ribosome. Examples include: SecM (secretion monitor) in E. coli — stalls translation to regulate secA expression in response to protein translocation capacity. MifM in B. subtilis — stalls to regulate membrane protein insertion machinery. Regulatory arrest peptides in fungi (uORFs) and the Arg attenuator peptide in N. crassa — sense small molecule concentrations. (3) Nascent chain compaction: Recent cryo-EM studies show that alpha-helices can form inside the wider vestibule region near the tunnel exit. The tunnel permits some secondary structure formation but constrains tertiary folding. (4) Interaction with chaperones: The tunnel exit is surrounded by a docking platform for co-translational chaperones and targeting factors (SRP, NAC, Hsp70/Ssb, TF/trigger factor), all of which bind near the exit port to assist the emerging nascent chain.

questions.question: Certain genetic diseases are caused by mutations that affect mRNA splicing rather than protein coding sequences. Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is caused by loss of the SMN1 gene, but humans have a nearly identical paralog, SMN2, that fails to compensate because of a single C-to-T transition in exon 7. How does this silent/synonymous change cause disease?
options: The C-to-T change disrupts an exonic splicing enhancer (ESE) in exon 7 and creates an exonic splicing silencer (ESS), causing predominant skipping of exon 7 during SMN2 pre-mRNA splicing, which produces an unstable, truncated SMN protein (SMN-delta7) that is rapidly degraded
The C-to-T change introduces a premature stop codon in SMN2 exon 7
The mutation prevents RNA Pol II from transcribing through exon 7
The T nucleotide causes the SMN2 mRNA to be retained in the nucleus and never translated
questions.explanation: Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is the leading genetic cause of infant mortality, caused by homozygous loss or mutation of the SMN1 (Survival Motor Neuron 1) gene. The nearly identical SMN2 gene differs from SMN1 at only a few positions, but a critical C-to-T transition at position 6 of exon 7 (C6T, c.840C>T) has devastating consequences for splicing despite being translationally silent (both codons encode the same amino acid): (1) In SMN1 (C at position 6): The exonic sequence with C creates a binding site for the splicing activator SF2/ASF (SRSF1, an SR protein). This ESE promotes U2AF and U1 snRNP recruitment to the flanking splice sites, ensuring exon 7 inclusion. Full-length SMN protein is produced. (2) In SMN2 (T at position 6): The C-to-T change disrupts the SF2/ASF ESE binding site and simultaneously creates a binding site for the splicing repressor hnRNP A1, which functions as an ESS. The combined loss of enhancer and gain of silencer causes ~90% exon 7 skipping. (3) The predominantly produced mRNA lacking exon 7 encodes SMN-delta7, a truncated protein that fails to oligomerize properly and is rapidly degraded by the proteasome. Only ~10% of SMN2 transcripts include exon 7, producing insufficient full-length SMN protein for motor neuron survival. (4) Therapeutic breakthrough: The antisense oligonucleotide nusinersen (Spinraza) and the small molecule risdiplam (Evrysdi) both promote SMN2 exon 7 inclusion by modifying splicing regulation, effectively converting SMN2 into a functional SMN1-like gene.

questions.question: The process of nuclear mRNA quality control involves the TRAMP complex working with the nuclear exosome. What is the molecular composition and function of the TRAMP complex?
options: TRAMP exports mature mRNAs through nuclear pores using its ATPase activity

TRAMP consists of the poly-A polymerase Trf4/5, the RNA-binding protein Air1/2, and the RNA helicase Mtr4; it adds short oligo-A tails to aberrant nuclear RNAs (improperly processed pre-mRNAs, defective tRNAs, cryptic transcripts), marking them for 3'-to-5' degradation by the nuclear exosome
TRAMP is a DNA repair complex that fixes transcription-associated DNA damage
TRAMP is a histone modification complex that acetylates histones at active promoters
questions.explanation: The TRAMP complex (Trf4/5-Air1/2-Mtr4 Polyadenylation complex) is a central component of the nuclear RNA surveillance system. Its composition and function: (1) Trf4 (or Trf5): A non-canonical poly-A polymerase that adds short oligo-A tails (~3-5 adenines) to aberrant RNA substrates. Unlike canonical poly-A polymerase (PAP) that adds long poly-A tails for mRNA stabilization, TRAMP's short oligo-A tails serve as degradation signals. (2) Air1 (or Air2): A zinc-knuckle RNA-binding protein that provides substrate specificity by recognizing structural features of aberrant RNAs. (3) Mtr4: A DEAD-box-related (DEXH) RNA helicase that unwinds RNA structures and feeds single-stranded RNA into the exosome channel. Mtr4 also bridges TRAMP to the exosome. (4) The nuclear exosome (core ring + Rrp44/Dis3 and Rrp6 catalytic subunits) degrades the oligo-A-tailed substrates in the 3'-to-5' direction. Rrp6 is nuclear-specific and plays a key role in quality control. (5) Targets of TRAMP-exosome surveillance include: improperly processed pre-rRNAs, defective tRNAs that fail modification or folding, hypomodified snRNAs/snoRNAs, pre-mRNAs that fail to complete splicing or 3' processing, cryptic unstable transcripts (CUTs) from pervasive transcription, and antisense RNAs. This system ensures that only properly processed, functional RNAs accumulate in the nucleus and are exported.

questions.question: A researcher wants to determine whether a specific protein undergoes co-translational or post-translational folding. She needs to observe the folding state of the nascent chain while it is still attached to the ribosome. Which technique would provide real-time information about the conformational state of the ribosome-bound nascent chain?
options: X-ray crystallography of the free, fully translated protein

Fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) using genetically encoded fluorescent labels at specific positions in the nascent chain; by measuring FRET efficiency between donor and acceptor fluorophores on actively translating ribosomes arrested at defined points, she can determine whether distant parts of the chain are close enough to indicate folding
Size-exclusion chromatography of the purified protein after translation
Circular dichroism spectroscopy of the mRNA encoding the protein
questions.explanation: FRET (Fluorescence/Forster Resonance Energy Transfer) is an ideal technique for studying co-translational protein folding because it reports on intramolecular distances in real time: (1) Principle: FRET occurs when a donor fluorophore and an acceptor fluorophore are within 1-10 nm (the Forster distance). Energy transfer efficiency depends on the inverse sixth power of the distance, making FRET exquisitely sensitive to conformational changes. (2) Experimental setup: Two site-specific fluorescent labels are incorporated into the nascent chain at known positions. This can be achieved using: (a) Unnatural amino acid incorporation (amber suppression with fluorescent amino acids). (b) Enzymatic labeling (e.g., Sfp phosphopantetheinyl transferase with CoA-fluorophore conjugates). (c) Split fluorescent proteins. (3) Arrest at defined lengths: Translation can be arrested at specific chain lengths using arrest peptide sequences (SecM), rare codons with depleted tRNAs, or antibiotic addition. This creates a panel of ribosome-nascent chain complexes at different stages of translation. (4) Measurement: If folding has occurred, the two labels will be brought into FRET proximity (high FRET efficiency). If the chain is still unfolded/extended, the labels will be far apart (low FRET efficiency). (5) By measuring FRET at progressively longer chain lengths, the researcher can determine exactly when during translation each domain folds. Single-molecule FRET variants provide information about folding dynamics and intermediate states.

questions.question: The exon junction complex (EJC) is deposited during splicing and remains on the mRNA until it is displaced by the pioneer round of translation. Besides its role in NMD, what other functions does the EJC serve?
options: The EJC exclusively functions in nonsense-mediated decay and has no other roles
The EJC protects mRNA from deadenylation by coating the entire mRNA body
The EJC is a transcription factor that activates downstream gene expression

The EJC enhances mRNA nuclear export by recruiting the TREX complex, promotes translation efficiency through interactions with the PYM protein that bridges the EJC to the 40S ribosomal subunit, and facilitates mRNA localization through its interaction with oskar mRNA in Drosophila
questions.explanation: The exon junction complex (EJC), deposited 20-24 nucleotides upstream of exon-exon junctions during splicing, is a remarkably multifunctional complex. Its core consists of eIF4AIII (a DEAD-box RNA helicase locked on the RNA), Y14 (MAGOH-interacting), MAGOH, and MLN51 (Barentsz/CASC3). Beyond NMD, the EJC has several important functions: (1) mRNA nuclear export: The EJC recruits the TREX (Transcription-Export) complex, particularly the adaptor protein ALY/REF, which in turn recruits the NXF1-NXT1 mRNA export receptor. Spliced mRNAs are exported more efficiently than identical cDNA-derived mRNAs lacking EJCs. (2) Translation enhancement: The EJC-associated factor PYM (Partner of Y14 and MAGOH) contains a domain that directly binds the 48S ribosomal pre-initiation complex (specifically the 40S subunit via interaction with h44 of 18S rRNA). This PYM-mediated bridge between the EJC and the ribosome enhances the first (pioneer) round of translation. Spliced mRNAs are translated ~2-fold more efficiently than their intronless counterparts. (3) mRNA localization: In Drosophila, the EJC core component eIF4AIII is required for proper localization of oskar mRNA to the posterior pole of the oocyte. The EJC (deposited after splicing of the first intron) recruits Barentsz and other localization factors. (4) Splicing regulation: EJCs deposited on upstream exons can influence alternative splicing decisions of nearby downstream introns.

questions.question: The triplet binding assay developed by Nirenberg and Leder was instrumental in assigning specific codons to amino acids. How does this assay work, and why was it more practical than the poly-U type experiments for complete codon assignments?
options: Short trinucleotides (synthetic codons) are incubated with ribosomes and radiolabeled aminoacyl-tRNAs; the cognate aminoacyl-tRNA binds the ribosome-trinucleotide complex and is retained on a nitrocellulose filter, while unbound tRNAs pass through; this allowed testing of all 64 possible codons individually with defined sequences
Trinucleotides are used as primers for reverse transcriptase to decode mRNA sequences
The assay measures the rate of amino acid incorporation into proteins rather than binding
The triplet binding assay uses whole cells instead of cell-free systems for more physiological conditions
questions.explanation: The Nirenberg and Leder triplet binding assay (1964) was a technically elegant approach that accelerated the complete decipherment of the genetic code. The method exploits the fact that trinucleotides, even without the rest of an mRNA, can program the ribosome to bind the cognate aminoacyl-tRNA in the P site: (1) Methodology: Each of the 64 possible trinucleotides (synthesized chemically) is incubated with E. coli ribosomes and a mixture of aminoacyl-tRNAs, one of which is radiolabeled. The mixture is passed through a nitrocellulose filter. Ribosomes (and any bound aminoacyl-tRNA) are retained on the filter, while free aminoacyl-tRNA passes through. (2) Readout: If the radiolabeled aminoacyl-tRNA is cognate for the tested trinucleotide, it will bind the ribosome and be retained on the filter (detectable radioactivity). Non-cognate tRNAs are not retained. (3) Advantages over poly-nucleotide experiments: (a) Each trinucleotide has a defined, unambiguous sequence — no reading frame ambiguity. (b) All 64 codons can be tested individually and systematically. (c) Only microgram quantities of synthetic trinucleotides are needed (vs. milligrams of polynucleotides). (d) The assay is rapid and can be parallelized. (4) This approach assigned amino acids to ~50 of the 64 codons. Combined with Khorana's repeating copolymer experiments and the earlier poly-U/poly-A/poly-C work, the complete genetic code was deciphered by 1966.

questions.question: Eukaryotic mRNA undergoes quality control at multiple stages. The pioneer round of translation is the first ribosome to translate a newly exported mRNA and plays a critical role in mRNA surveillance. How does the pioneer round differ from subsequent steady-state translation rounds?
options: The pioneer round uses different ribosomes (40S instead of 80S) and translates only the first 10 codons
The pioneer round occurs in the nucleus before mRNA export

During the pioneer round, the 5' cap is bound by the cap-binding complex CBC (CBP80/CBP20) rather than eIF4E, and the mRNA retains EJCs that are displaced as the ribosome translates through exon-exon junctions; this allows NMD to detect premature stop codons during the first round before transitioning to eIF4E-bound steady-state translation
There is no difference between pioneer and steady-state translation rounds
questions.explanation: The pioneer round of translation is a quality control checkpoint that occurs on newly exported mRNAs before they enter the steady-state translation pool: (1) Cap-binding complex (CBC): During and immediately after nuclear export, the 5' cap is bound by CBC (CBP80/CBP20 heterodimer), NOT by eIF4E. CBC was loaded onto the cap in the nucleus during transcription. The CBC-bound mRNA uses a distinct initiation pathway involving CTIF (CBP80/20-dependent translation initiation factor) instead of the canonical eIF4G. (2) EJC presence: Newly exported mRNAs retain EJCs at exon-exon junctions (deposited during splicing). These are critical for NMD surveillance. (3) Pioneer translation: The first ribosome translates through the mRNA, displacing EJCs as it moves through each exon-exon junction. If it encounters a premature termination codon (PTC) with one or more downstream EJCs remaining, the NMD pathway is triggered (UPF1-UPF2/UPF3b interaction at the EJC, followed by mRNA degradation). (4) Transition to steady state: After successful pioneer round translation (no PTC detected), several remodeling events occur: CBC is replaced by eIF4E (mediated by importin-alpha and eIF4E binding), remaining EJCs are displaced, and PABPN1 is replaced by PABPC1 on the poly-A tail. The mRNA is now in its steady-state form, translated efficiently by the canonical eIF4E-dependent pathway. (5) This two-phase system ensures that only mRNAs encoding functional proteins enter the highly efficient steady-state translation pool.

questions.question: Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases must correctly identify their cognate tRNAs from a pool of ~45 different tRNA species. Beyond the anticodon, what other tRNA structural features serve as identity elements for synthetase recognition?
options: The TpsiC loop contains the sole identity element recognized by all synthetases
Only the anticodon trinucleotide is used for tRNA identity in all synthetases

The discriminator base at position 73 (the unpaired nucleotide between the acceptor stem and the CCA end), specific base pairs in the acceptor stem, and variable loop length and sequence; for alanyl-tRNA synthetase, a single G3:U70 wobble base pair in the acceptor stem is the primary identity determinant
The D-loop sequence is the universal recognition element for all synthetases
questions.explanation: tRNA identity — the set of structural features that enable a specific aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase to recognize its cognate tRNA(s) — involves multiple distributed elements, creating a complex 'recognition code.' Major identity elements include: (1) Discriminator base (position 73): The unpaired nucleotide immediately 3' of the acceptor stem and 5' of the CCA tail. This single base is an identity element for many synthetases. For example, A73 is critical for E. coli histidyl-tRNA synthetase recognition. (2) Acceptor stem: The first 3-4 base pairs of the acceptor stem are identity elements for several synthetases. The most dramatic example is E. coli alanyl-tRNA synthetase (AlaRS), where a single G3:U70 wobble base pair in the acceptor stem is necessary and sufficient for alanylation. Transplanting G3:U70 into any other tRNA causes it to be misacylated with alanine. (3) Anticodon: For most synthetases, the anticodon nucleotides (positions 34, 35, 36) are major identity elements. However, some synthetases (AlaRS, SerRS, LeuRS) do not use the anticodon at all. (4) Variable loop: The length and sequence of the variable loop (between the anticodon stem and TpsiC stem) contributes to identity for several synthetases, particularly seryl-tRNA synthetase (long variable arm). (5) Other elements: Specific nucleotides in the D-loop, TpsiC loop, and internal positions contribute to identity in some systems. Anti-determinants (features that prevent recognition by non-cognate synthetases) also exist, adding another layer of specificity. The operational RNA code (acceptor stem recognition) and the classical code (anticodon recognition) may represent an ancient two-domain origin of the tRNA molecule.

questions.question: A lab performs global translation analysis using 35S-methionine pulse labeling in yeast cells before and after rapamycin treatment (which inhibits mTORC1). Total protein synthesis drops to 30% of control within 30 minutes. However, polysome profiling shows that the polysome-to-monosome ratio (P/M ratio) only decreases to 60% of control. What explains this discrepancy between global translation rate and polysome distribution?
options: Rapamycin-mediated mTORC1 inhibition primarily reduces translation initiation rate (via 4E-BP dephosphorylation), which decreases ribosome loading onto mRNAs; however, ribosomes already on mRNAs continue to elongate, and the elongation rate itself may also decrease (via eEF2 kinase activation and eEF2 phosphorylation), causing ribosomes to spend more time on each mRNA and partially maintaining polysome size
The P/M ratio is not a reliable indicator of translation rate
The discrepancy is due to measurement error in the 35S-methionine incorporation assay
Rapamycin causes selective degradation of monosomes but not polysomes
questions.explanation: The discrepancy between global translation rate reduction (70% decrease) and polysome-to-monosome ratio change (40% decrease) reveals that mTORC1 inhibition affects both initiation and elongation: (1) Initiation rate reduction: mTORC1 inhibition by rapamycin causes 4E-BP dephosphorylation, sequestering eIF4E and reducing eIF4F complex formation. This decreases the rate at which new ribosomes load onto mRNAs (initiation). If initiation were the only affected step, we would expect a greater shift from polysomes to monosomes (proportional to the translation decrease). (2) Elongation rate reduction: mTORC1 also regulates translation elongation through S6K1-mediated phosphorylation of eEF2 kinase. When mTORC1 is inhibited, eEF2 kinase becomes active and phosphorylates eEF2 at Thr56, reducing its activity. Phospho-eEF2 is less effective at catalyzing ribosomal translocation, slowing elongation. (3) Combined effect on polysomes: Reduced initiation tends to decrease the number of ribosomes per mRNA (smaller polysomes). Reduced elongation tends to keep ribosomes on mRNAs longer (maintaining or even increasing polysome size). These opposing effects partially cancel out in the P/M ratio. (4) Net translation rate: Both reduced initiation (fewer starts per mRNA per time) AND reduced elongation (slower amino acid addition) contribute to the 70% decrease in global protein synthesis. But the P/M ratio reflects only the balance between ribosome loading and transit, explaining why it changes less dramatically. This illustrates why P/M ratio alone is insufficient to quantify translation rate — ribosome profiling combined with metabolic labeling provides a more complete picture.

questions.question: The genetic code shows a non-random pattern in codon assignments that minimizes the impact of point mutations. How does the structure of the code provide robustness against single-nucleotide substitution errors?
options: The code is completely random with no pattern in codon assignments
The genetic code prevents mutations by repairing DNA errors during replication
All mutations in the genetic code are lethal regardless of position

Synonymous codons typically differ at the third (wobble) position, where mutations cause no amino acid change; when first or second position mutations do change the amino acid, the resulting amino acid usually has similar chemical properties to the original, because codons for chemically similar amino acids occupy adjacent positions in the codon table
questions.explanation: The genetic code exhibits a highly non-random structure that appears to have been optimized by natural selection to minimize the deleterious effects of mutations and translational errors. This 'error-minimization' property is evident at multiple levels: (1) Third position (wobble) degeneracy: Most degeneracy in the code is concentrated at the third codon position. For example, all four codons GGN encode glycine, and all four GCN encode alanine. Single nucleotide changes at the third position most often produce synonymous (silent) mutations. This is also where wobble base pairing occurs, tolerating translational misreading at this position. (2) Similar amino acids share codons: Amino acids with similar physicochemical properties tend to have related codons, so non-synonymous substitutions often produce conservative changes. For example: (a) Hydrophobic amino acids (Leu, Ile, Val, Met, Phe) have codons starting with U. (b) Acidic amino acids (Asp, Glu) share GA- codons. (c) Basic amino acids (Arg, Lys) share AG- codons. (d) First position changes often swap between chemically similar amino acids. (3) Second position: Changes at the second position tend to have the largest chemical impact, but even here the code provides some buffering. (4) Statistical analyses comparing the natural code to millions of random codes show that the actual genetic code is in the top 0.01% for error minimization — far better than expected by chance. However, whether this reflects direct selection on the code or stereochemical affinities between amino acids and their codons (or both) remains debated.

questions.question: Kozak's leaky scanning model explains how some eukaryotic mRNAs produce two or more protein isoforms from different AUG start codons. What determines whether a ribosome initiates at the first AUG or scans past it to a downstream AUG?
options: The 5' cap structure directs ribosomes to specific AUG codons based on distance

The sequence context around the first AUG (Kozak consensus): if the first AUG is in a weak context (no purine at -3, no G at +4), a fraction of scanning 40S subunits bypass it and initiate at the next AUG in strong context, producing two proteins from one mRNA
Ribosomes always initiate at the first AUG regardless of surrounding sequence
Alternative sigma factors in the cytoplasm select different start codons
questions.explanation: Leaky scanning is a natural regulatory mechanism that enables production of multiple protein isoforms from a single mRNA species. The underlying principle is that AUG recognition by the scanning 43S pre-initiation complex is not binary but is influenced by the surrounding sequence context (Kozak consensus: GCC(A/G)CCAUGG): (1) Strong context AUG: When the first AUG has a purine (especially A) at position -3 and G at position +4, virtually all scanning ribosomes recognize it. No leaky scanning occurs, and only one protein is made. (2) Weak context AUG: When the first AUG lacks one or both of these critical positions, a fraction (10-50%) of scanning ribosomes bypass it without initiating. These ribosomes continue scanning and initiate at the next AUG encountered (usually in a stronger context). (3) Biological significance: This produces two protein isoforms differing at their N-termini. The longer isoform (from AUG1) may contain a signal peptide, nuclear localization signal, or mitochondrial targeting sequence that the shorter isoform (from AUG2) lacks, directing the two isoforms to different cellular compartments. (4) Examples: Human c-Myc produces p67-Myc (from upstream CUG) and p64-Myc (from downstream AUG). FGF-2 produces multiple isoforms with different localizations. Several transcription factors use leaky scanning for functional diversification.

questions.question: Transcription by RNA Pol II in eukaryotes is bidirectional at many promoters, producing both sense mRNA and upstream antisense transcripts. These divergent transcripts arise from bidirectional promoters. What determines the asymmetric fate of sense versus antisense transcripts?
options: Both sense and antisense transcripts are equally stable and functional
Only the sense strand DNA can be transcribed by RNA Pol II

Sense transcripts are stabilized by efficient 5' capping, splicing, and polyadenylation, while upstream antisense transcripts (PROMPTs/uaRNAs) lack proper processing signals and are rapidly degraded by the nuclear exosome and TRAMP complex
Antisense transcripts are immediately converted to siRNAs by Dicer
questions.explanation: Pervasive bidirectional transcription is a widespread feature of eukaryotic genomes. At most active promoters, RNA Pol II initiates in both directions, but the resulting transcripts have strikingly different fates: Sense (downstream) transcripts: (1) Pol II elongating in the sense direction encounters U1 snRNP binding sites (5' splice sites) early in the transcript, which suppress premature cleavage/polyadenylation. (2) Proper processing occurs: capping, splicing, and polyadenylation at the canonical poly(A) signal. (3) The processed mRNA is exported and translated. (4) Ser2 CTD phosphorylation by P-TEFb promotes productive elongation. Antisense (upstream) transcripts — PROMPTs (Promoter Upstream Transcripts) or uaRNAs: (1) The antisense direction typically lacks U1 binding sites but contains early polyadenylation signals (PAS/AAUAAA). (2) These transcripts are cleaved and receive short poly-A tails by the TRAMP complex's Trf4/5 polymerase. (3) The nuclear exosome (with Rrp6) rapidly degrades these transcripts 3'-to-5'. (4) Additionally, Nrd1-Nab3-Sen1 (NNS) complex in yeast recognizes specific sequence motifs in antisense transcripts and terminates transcription early. (5) The integrator complex can also cleave these transcripts. This 'U1-PAS axis' model explains how the same bidirectional promoter produces stable sense transcripts and unstable antisense transcripts based on the asymmetric distribution of RNA processing signals in the flanking genomic sequence.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about RNA modifications and their biological significance:
S1: The 5' cap structure (m7GpppN) protects mRNA from 5'-to-3' exonucleolytic degradation and is recognized by eIF4E for translation initiation
S2: Pseudouridine (the most abundant RNA modification) is found in tRNA, rRNA, and mRNA, and can affect RNA structure and translational fidelity
S3: 2'-O-methylation of the first and second nucleotides after the cap (Cap1 and Cap2 modifications) is required to distinguish self from non-self RNA in the innate immune system
S4: RNA modifications are irreversible and cannot be dynamically regulated
options: S1-True, S2-True, S3-True, S4-False
S1-True, S2-True, S3-True, S4-True
S1-True, S2-False, S3-True, S4-False
S1-True, S2-True, S3-False, S4-True
questions.explanation: S1 is TRUE: The 5' cap (m7GpppN, added co-transcriptionally) has multiple essential functions: (a) Protection from 5'-to-3' exonucleases like Xrn1/Xrn2 by blocking access to the free 5' end. (b) Recruitment of the translation initiation factor eIF4E, which is the rate-limiting cap-binding component of the eIF4F complex. (c) Promotion of nuclear export via PHAX and CBC-mediated pathways. (d) Enhancement of splicing of the first intron through CBC interactions. S2 is TRUE: Pseudouridine (psi) is the most abundant modified nucleoside, found in all RNA types. In tRNA and rRNA, psi stabilizes RNA structure through an additional hydrogen bond (the free N1-H not present in uridine). In mRNA, psi (introduced by pseudouridine synthases or guided by H/ACA snoRNAs) can affect translation fidelity, mRNA stability, and immunogenicity. Notably, pseudouridine-modified mRNA was critical for the success of COVID-19 mRNA vaccines (Kariko and Weissman, Nobel Prize 2023). S3 is TRUE: The 2'-O-methylation of the first transcribed nucleotide (Cap1, position +1) and second nucleotide (Cap2, position +2) serves as a molecular 'self' marker. The innate immune sensor IFIT1 specifically recognizes mRNAs lacking 2'-O-methylation at Cap1 as foreign (non-self), triggering an antiviral interferon response. Many viruses have evolved their own 2'-O-methyltransferases to evade this detection. S4 is FALSE: Many RNA modifications are dynamically regulated and reversible. m6A (the most studied) is reversibly installed by METTL3/METTL14 (writers) and removed by FTO/ALKBH5 (erasers). Pseudouridine, while not yet shown to be directly reversed, can be regulated by controlling pseudouridine synthase expression.

questions.question: The Mediator kinase module contains CDK8, Cyclin C, MED12, and MED13. This module can act as either a transcriptional repressor or activator depending on context. How does the kinase module function as a repressor of Pol II transcription?
options: The kinase module sterically blocks Pol II association with the Mediator complex by occupying the Pol II-binding surface; CDK8 can also phosphorylate transcription factors (like Notch ICD) and histone H3S10, creating both activating and repressing marks depending on the genomic context
The kinase module degrades all mRNA produced by Pol II
The kinase module recruits histone deacetylases to silence all active genes
CDK8 phosphorylates DNA directly, preventing template strand access
questions.explanation: The Mediator kinase module has a complex, context-dependent role in transcription regulation: Repressive function: (1) Structural occlusion: Cryo-EM structures show that the kinase module binds to the Mediator in a position that overlaps with the Pol II-binding surface on the head and middle modules. When the kinase module is associated, it physically prevents Pol II from docking on Mediator, blocking PIC formation. (2) CDK8-mediated phosphorylation of activators: CDK8 can phosphorylate gene-specific transcription factors, targeting them for ubiquitination and degradation. For example, CDK8 phosphorylates Notch intracellular domain (NICD), GCN4, and SREBP, promoting their turnover. (3) Phosphorylation of cyclin H: CDK8 phosphorylates cyclin H (a subunit of TFIIH), potentially modulating TFIIH kinase activity and CTD phosphorylation. Activating function: (4) Paradoxically, CDK8 can also promote transcription at certain genes. CDK8 phosphorylates histone H3S10, which is associated with transcriptional activation. (5) CDK8 activates P-TEFb by phosphorylating the HEXIM1 protein, releasing P-TEFb from the inhibitory 7SK snRNP complex. (6) At super-enhancer-driven genes, CDK8/Mediator kinase module cooperates with BRD4 to sustain high-level transcription. The dual function depends on gene-specific regulatory contexts, explaining why CDK8 can act as both an oncogene and a tumor suppressor depending on the cancer type.

questions.question: A researcher compares the translation of a reporter mRNA with and without a 5' cap. In a cell-free translation system from wheat germ, the capped mRNA is translated 20-fold more efficiently than the uncapped version. However, when she adds the cap analog m7GTP (free cap) to the capped mRNA translation reaction, translation is dramatically inhibited. What is the mechanism of inhibition by free cap analog?
options: The free cap analog is incorporated into the mRNA, replacing the existing cap
m7GTP is toxic to the ribosomes and causes their disassembly
The cap analog activates an mRNA-degrading nuclease

The free m7GTP cap analog competitively binds to eIF4E, sequestering this limiting initiation factor away from the capped mRNA; since eIF4E must bind the mRNA cap to recruit the 43S pre-initiation complex, competition by free cap analog prevents the mRNA from engaging the translation machinery
questions.explanation: This classic experiment demonstrates the essential role of the 5' cap-eIF4E interaction in translation initiation and has been used extensively to study cap-dependent vs. cap-independent translation. The mechanism: (1) eIF4E recognition: eIF4E is the cap-binding subunit of the eIF4F initiation complex. It has a concave binding surface with conserved tryptophan residues (W56, W102 in human eIF4E) that sandwich the m7G base through stacking interactions. The binding affinity for m7GTP is approximately 100 nM. (2) Competitive inhibition: Free m7GTP has the same chemical structure as the cap of mRNA and therefore competes for the same binding pocket on eIF4E. Since eIF4E is typically present at limiting concentrations in cell extracts (the least abundant translation initiation factor), adding excess free cap analog saturates the available eIF4E. (3) Effect on translation: With eIF4E sequestered by free cap analog, capped mRNAs cannot recruit eIF4F, preventing 43S PIC recruitment and cap-dependent scanning. Translation is inhibited in a dose-dependent manner. (4) Control experiment utility: Cap analog competition is a widely used tool to demonstrate that translation of a specific mRNA is cap-dependent. mRNAs that remain translated in the presence of cap analog are presumed to use cap-independent mechanisms (IRES). However, as noted earlier, controls for cryptic promoter activity are also needed. (5) Practical application: Cap analogs are also used during in vitro mRNA synthesis (e.g., for mRNA vaccines) as anti-reverse cap analogs (ARCAs) that ensure the cap is incorporated in the correct orientation.

questions.question: In the context of bacterial gene expression, what is the fundamental difference between an inducible and a repressible operon in terms of the relationship between the regulatory molecule (effector) and the repressor protein?
options: Inducible operons use activators while repressible operons use silencers at the chromatin level
Both types use identical regulatory mechanisms but respond to different environmental signals

In inducible operons (like lac), the inducer molecule binds the repressor and inactivates it, allowing transcription; in repressible operons (like trp), the corepressor molecule binds the aporepressor and activates it, enabling DNA binding and transcription repression
Inducible operons are always polycistronic while repressible operons are monocistronic
questions.explanation: Inducible and repressible operons represent two fundamental strategies for bacterial transcriptional regulation, differing in the relationship between the effector molecule and the repressor: Inducible operons (e.g., lac operon): (1) Default state: The repressor (LacI) is constitutively expressed and binds the operator in the absence of inducer, blocking transcription. The operon is OFF by default. (2) Induction: When the inducer (allolactose, or the synthetic analog IPTG) is present, it binds the repressor protein and causes a conformational change (allosteric change) that reduces the repressor's affinity for the operator DNA. The repressor releases from the operator, and RNA polymerase can transcribe the structural genes. (3) Logic: The inducer INACTIVATES the repressor → operon ON. Repressible operons (e.g., trp operon): (1) Default state: The aporepressor (TrpR) is constitutively expressed but in its inactive form cannot bind the operator. The operon is ON by default. (2) Repression: When the corepressor (tryptophan) accumulates, it binds the aporepressor and causes a conformational change that enables DNA binding. The activated repressor-corepressor complex binds the operator and blocks transcription. (3) Logic: The corepressor ACTIVATES the repressor → operon OFF. This design is logical from a metabolic perspective: catabolic operons (lac) are induced when the substrate is present, while biosynthetic operons (trp) are repressed when the product accumulates, providing negative feedback.

questions.question: The concept of codon context describes how the identity of neighboring codons affects translation speed and accuracy. What molecular mechanism explains why a rare codon followed by another rare codon has a more severe effect on translation than two rare codons separated by common codons?
options: Consecutive rare codons cause ribosome queuing and collision: the first rare codon slows the ribosome, and if the next codon is also rare, the already-slowed ribosome stalls further, creating a traffic jam that triggers ribosome collisions with upstream ribosomes and potential quality control activation
The tRNA pool is refreshed between common codons but cannot recover between consecutive rare codons
Adjacent rare codons chemically interact with each other in the mRNA, forming a structure that blocks the ribosome
Consecutive rare codons change the reading frame, causing the ribosome to produce an incorrect protein
questions.explanation: Codon context effects on translation reflect the dynamics of ribosome traffic on mRNA and the kinetics of tRNA selection: (1) Isolated rare codons: When a ribosome encounters a single rare codon, it pauses briefly while waiting for the scarce cognate tRNA. If the next codon is common (abundant tRNA), the ribosome quickly resumes normal speed. The pause is transient and usually does not significantly affect overall translation. (2) Consecutive rare codons: When two or more rare codons occur in succession, the ribosome experiences compounded delays. The first rare codon slows the ribosome, and before it can recover speed, it encounters the second rare codon, causing further slowing. This cumulative effect can lead to: (a) Extended ribosome stalling, which may trigger quality control pathways (NGD, RQC). (b) Ribosome queuing: Upstream ribosomes catch up to the stalled one, forming a queue. (c) Ribosome collisions: When the trailing ribosome collides with the stalled one, the unique disome interface is recognized by ZNF598/Hel2, triggering ubiquitination and potential mRNA cleavage. (3) Separated rare codons: When rare codons are separated by several common codons, the ribosome has time to return to normal speed between encounters. Each rare codon is experienced independently, and the pauses do not compound. (4) This principle is relevant for heterologous gene expression: codon-optimized genes that inadvertently cluster rare codons can have translation problems even if the overall codon adaptation index (CAI) is favorable.

questions.question: A researcher discovers that a specific protein is abnormally localized to the cytoplasm in disease cells instead of the ER. She hypothesizes that a mutation in the signal peptide prevents SRP recognition. What experiment would test whether the mutant signal peptide fails to engage the SRP pathway?
options: Sequence the entire protein-coding region to look for other mutations

Perform in vitro translation of the wild-type and mutant mRNAs in the presence and absence of canine pancreatic microsomes; wild-type protein should be glycosylated (larger molecular weight) when microsomes are present, while the mutant should remain unglycosylated regardless of microsome addition, indicating failed translocation
Run a Western blot to compare protein expression levels between wild-type and mutant
Stain the cells with a fluorescent dye to visualize protein localization
questions.explanation: The in vitro translation/translocation assay with microsomal membranes is the classical experiment for testing signal peptide function and SRP-dependent ER targeting: (1) Experimental setup: mRNAs encoding wild-type and mutant proteins are translated in a cell-free system (typically rabbit reticulocyte lysate, which contains SRP) either without membranes (translation only) or with canine pancreatic rough microsomes (translation + translocation). (2) Wild-type signal peptide: With microsomes, the signal peptide engages SRP co-translationally, the ribosome-nascent chain complex docks at the ER translocon (Sec61 in the microsomal membrane), and the protein is translocated into the microsomal lumen. Inside, the signal peptide is cleaved by signal peptidase (making the protein slightly smaller), and N-linked glycosylation occurs at Asn-X-Ser/Thr sequons (making the protein ~2-3 kDa larger per glycosylation site). The glycosylated, signal-cleaved protein is diagnostic of successful translocation. (3) Mutant signal peptide: If the mutation prevents SRP recognition (e.g., reduced hydrophobicity), the protein fails to engage the SRP pathway, is not targeted to microsomes, and remains in the reticulocyte lysate as a full-length, unglycosylated precursor — identical to the minus-microsome control. (4) Additional controls: Protease protection assay (adding proteinase K to microsomes — translocated proteins are protected inside sealed vesicles while untranslocated proteins are digested), and SRP depletion/reconstitution experiments to specifically test the SRP dependence.

questions.question: Ribose methylation (2'-O-methylation) is one of the most abundant modifications in ribosomal RNA, with ~100 sites in human rRNA. These modifications are guided by small nucleolar RNAs (snoRNAs). What is the molecular mechanism by which box C/D snoRNAs direct site-specific 2'-O-methylation?
options: Box C/D snoRNAs recruit DNA methyltransferases to modify the rDNA genes rather than the rRNA transcripts
snoRNAs directly catalyze the methylation reaction without any protein partner

Box C/D snoRNAs contain 10-21 nucleotide guide sequences complementary to the target rRNA site; the target nucleotide to be methylated is positioned exactly 5 nucleotides upstream of the box D (or D') element; the associated methyltransferase fibrillarin (Nop1 in yeast) catalyzes the methyl transfer from S-adenosylmethionine to the 2'-hydroxyl of the selected ribose
The rRNA modification sites are pre-determined by the rRNA sequence and require no guide
questions.explanation: Box C/D snoRNAs (small nucleolar RNAs) are guide RNAs that direct site-specific 2'-O-methylation of ribosomal RNA through an elegant base-pairing mechanism: (1) snoRNA structure: Box C/D snoRNAs contain two conserved sequence motifs — box C (RUGAUGA, near the 5' end) and box D (CUGA, near the 3' end), plus internal copies C' and D'. These boxes fold together to form a kink-turn (K-turn) structure that serves as a binding platform for snoRNP proteins. (2) Guide sequences: Between the C and D (or C' and D') boxes, there are 10-21 nucleotide antisense sequences complementary to the target rRNA. The snoRNA-rRNA base pairing positions the methylation target precisely. (3) Fifth nucleotide rule: The nucleotide that will be methylated is ALWAYS the one base-paired to the fifth nucleotide upstream of box D (or D'). This invariant spacing provides the molecular ruler for target selection. (4) Enzymatic machinery: The snoRNP complex includes four core proteins: fibrillarin (the SAM-dependent 2'-O-methyltransferase that catalyzes the actual modification), NOP56, NOP58 (scaffold proteins), and SNU13/15.5K (K-turn binding protein). (5) Each snoRNA can guide methylation at one or two sites (using D and D' guide sequences). Humans have ~100 box C/D snoRNAs collectively modifying ~100 rRNA positions. (6) These modifications cluster in functionally important regions of the ribosome (decoding center, PTC) and fine-tune ribosome structure and function.

questions.question: Nonsense-mediated decay (NMD) has been shown to regulate expression of approximately 5-10% of all human genes, not just those with mutations. How can wild-type genes produce NMD-sensitive transcripts that are regulated by this pathway?
options: Alternative splicing can introduce premature termination codons: exon inclusion or intron retention events that place stop codons upstream of exon junctions generate NMD-sensitive isoforms; this alternative splicing-NMD coupling (AS-NMD or RUST) serves as a regulatory mechanism to fine-tune gene expression
Wild-type genes cannot be regulated by NMD under any circumstances
NMD only recognizes transcripts with mutations in the start codon
NMD degrades all transcripts randomly to maintain mRNA homeostasis
questions.explanation: The coupling of alternative splicing with NMD (termed AS-NMD, RUST — Regulated Unproductive Splicing and Translation, or the 'NMD-switch') is a widespread gene regulatory mechanism affecting thousands of human genes: (1) Mechanism: Alternative splicing produces mRNA isoforms that contain premature termination codons (PTCs). These PTCs are located >50-55 nt upstream of an exon-exon junction (the NMD-triggering boundary), making the isoform an NMD substrate. The ratio of productive (translated) to unproductive (NMD-degraded) isoforms determines effective gene expression. (2) Types of NMD-inducing alternative splicing: (a) Poison exon inclusion: Inclusion of a short, conserved exon containing an in-frame stop codon. Many SR protein and hnRNP genes use poison exons for autoregulation. (b) Alternative 3'/5' splice site usage: Shifting the splice site introduces or removes stop codons from the reading frame. (c) Intron retention: Retained introns often contain stop codons that trigger NMD. (d) Exon skipping: Removing an exon can shift the reading frame to create a downstream PTC. (3) Autoregulation: Many splicing factors regulate their own expression through AS-NMD. When a splicing factor is abundant, it promotes splicing of its own pre-mRNA into an NMD-sensitive isoform, creating a homeostatic negative feedback loop. SRSF1-SRSF12 (SR proteins) and many hnRNP proteins use this mechanism. (4) Conservation: NMD-inducing alternative splicing events are often highly conserved across mammals, indicating functional importance. (5) ~35% of alternative splicing events in the human transcriptome are predicted to generate NMD-sensitive isoforms.

questions.question: Formylmethionine (fMet) is used as the initiator amino acid in bacteria but not in eukaryotes. What is the biochemical rationale for using fMet specifically for translation initiation, and why is the formyl group subsequently removed?
options: The formyl group provides extra stability to the initiator tRNA-ribosome interaction
The formyl group is needed for mRNA-tRNA codon-anticodon recognition at AUG

The formyl group on fMet blocks the alpha-amino group, preventing it from acting as a nucleophile in peptide bond formation at the P site; this ensures fMet-tRNA can only donate its amino acid to form the first peptide bond but cannot accept a peptide chain, maintaining correct initiation; the formyl group is removed by peptide deformylase after initiation because the blocked amino group is no longer needed
Formylation is a random modification that has no functional significance
questions.explanation: The use of N-formylmethionine (fMet) for bacterial translation initiation serves a precise biochemical function related to the chemistry of peptide bond formation: (1) Initiation chemistry: During translation initiation, the initiator tRNA (fMet-tRNAi) binds directly to the P site (not the A site). For the first peptide bond to form, the amino acid in the P site must act as a donor (its carbonyl carbon is attacked by the amino group of the A site amino acid). Critically, the P site amino acid must NOT act as an acceptor (its amino group should not attack anything). (2) The formyl group (HCO-) on the alpha-amino group of Met blocks this amino group, ensuring that fMet cannot serve as a nucleophilic acceptor. This prevents incorrect chemistry at the initiation step. (3) After the first peptide bond forms (transferring fMet to the A site aminoacyl-tRNA), the formyl group is no longer at the growing end of the chain. Peptide deformylase (PDF) removes the formyl group from the N-terminal methionine, and methionine aminopeptidase (MAP) often subsequently removes the Met entirely if the second amino acid is small. (4) In eukaryotes, the initiator Met-tRNAi is not formylated, but it has structural features that restrict it to the P site (specific base pairs recognized by eIF2, inability to bind to eEF1A/EF-Tu). (5) Interestingly, mitochondrial translation also uses fMet, consistent with the endosymbiotic origin of mitochondria from bacteria. The distinction between formylated (bacterial) and non-formylated (cytoplasmic) initiator amino acids is exploited by the innate immune system to detect bacterial proteins.

questions.question: RNA interference (RNAi) involves small RNA-mediated gene silencing. While typically covered in gene regulation (Ch 18), the process intersects with translation because miRNAs repress target mRNA translation. How does the miRNA-loaded RISC (RNA-Induced Silencing Complex) repress translation in animals?
options: miRISC, with AGO2 bound to the guide miRNA, base-pairs with partially complementary sites in the 3' UTR of target mRNAs and recruits GW182/TNRC6 proteins, which interact with the CCR4-NOT deadenylase complex to promote deadenylation, decapping, and translational repression through interference with eIF4F-mediated closed-loop formation
miRISC directly binds to ribosomes and prevents them from translating any mRNA
miRISC cleaves the mRNA at the miRNA binding site, destroying it immediately
miRNAs enhance translation of their target mRNAs by stabilizing polysome formation
questions.explanation: In animals, miRNAs typically bind their targets with imperfect complementarity (requiring only seed region pairing at positions 2-8) and repress gene expression through a combination of translational repression and mRNA destabilization: (1) miRISC assembly: The mature miRNA is loaded into Argonaute protein (AGO1-4 in mammals; AGO2 is the only one with slicer activity). The guide strand is retained and the passenger strand is discarded. (2) Target recognition: miRISC scans 3' UTRs for sites with complementarity to the miRNA seed region (positions 2-7/8 from the 5' end). Most animal miRNA targets have imperfect complementarity, which prevents AGO2-mediated cleavage. (3) GW182/TNRC6 recruitment: AGO proteins recruit GW182 family proteins (TNRC6A/B/C in mammals) through direct interaction with AGO's tryptophan-binding pockets. GW182 is the key effector of silencing. (4) Deadenylation: GW182 recruits the CCR4-NOT deadenylase complex (via direct interaction with NOT1 and NOT9/CNOT9) and PAN2-PAN3 complex. This accelerates poly-A tail shortening. (5) Translational repression: The mechanism involves disruption of the closed-loop mRNA structure. Deadenylation removes PABPC1, breaking the eIF4G-PABPC1 interaction. Additionally, GW182-NOT1 interaction may directly interfere with eIF4F assembly or cause ribosome drop-off. (6) Decapping and decay: Deadenylated mRNAs are decapped by DCP2 (promoted by DDX6 helicase, recruited by the CCR4-NOT complex) and degraded 5'-to-3' by XRN1. Current evidence suggests deadenylation-dependent mRNA decay is the dominant mechanism, with translational repression being an earlier, partially independent step.

questions.question: A researcher analyzes the proteome of yeast cells using quantitative mass spectrometry and finds that protein abundance varies over a 10,000-fold range (from <50 to >500,000 copies per cell), while mRNA abundance varies only ~100-fold. She calculates the protein-to-mRNA ratio for each gene and finds it varies ~1,000-fold. What does this disproportionate variation in protein-to-mRNA ratios reveal?
options: mRNA measurements are inaccurate and do not reflect true transcript levels
Protein abundance is determined entirely by gene copy number in the genome

Post-transcriptional regulation (translation rate and protein stability) contributes more to determining final protein abundance than transcription alone; genes with high protein-to-mRNA ratios have high translation rates or stable proteins, while those with low ratios are translationally repressed or encode unstable proteins
All mRNAs are translated at the same rate, so protein differences reflect only mRNA differences
questions.explanation: This observation, consistently found in global proteomics studies across yeast, mammals, and other organisms, reveals the dominant role of post-transcriptional regulation in determining protein abundance: (1) The protein-to-mRNA ratio (often called 'translation rate' proxy, though it integrates both translation efficiency and protein stability) varies ~1,000-fold between genes. This means that knowing an mRNA's abundance provides only a partial prediction of protein abundance. (2) Studies decomposing variance in protein levels have found that: (a) Transcription accounts for ~40-50% of the variance in protein abundance. (b) Translation rate accounts for ~30-40%. (c) Protein degradation rate accounts for ~10-20%. (d) mRNA degradation rate contributes indirectly. (3) Genes with high protein-to-mRNA ratios (highly efficient translation): Ribosomal proteins, glycolytic enzymes, and abundant structural proteins. These typically have: optimal codon usage, short/unstructured 5' UTRs, strong Kozak contexts, and encode stable proteins. (4) Genes with low protein-to-mRNA ratios (inefficient translation or unstable proteins): Regulatory proteins (transcription factors, kinases). These often have: uORFs in 5' UTRs, structured 5' UTRs, rare codon clusters, and short protein half-lives (due to PEST sequences or other degrons). (5) This quantitative framework demonstrates why gene expression is a multi-layered regulatory process. Cells use post-transcriptional mechanisms to fine-tune protein output beyond what transcription alone can achieve, enabling rapid responses and precise stoichiometric control.

questions.question: The Sec61 translocon channel must maintain the permeability barrier of the ER membrane while allowing protein translocation. How does the translocon prevent the leakage of calcium ions and other small molecules from the ER lumen during active translocation?
options: The translocon has a hydrophobic pore ring of six isoleucine residues that forms a gasket-like seal around the translocating polypeptide, while a short plug helix blocks the channel when it is idle; BiP/GRP78 on the lumenal side also helps seal the channel during translocation pauses
The translocon is too narrow for calcium ions to pass through under any conditions
The translocon channel is always open and ER calcium leakage is prevented solely by calcium pumps
The ribosome physically seals the cytoplasmic side of the channel during translocation
questions.explanation: The Sec61 translocon must solve a fundamental biophysical challenge: it must allow polypeptide chains to cross the membrane while maintaining the ER's electrochemical gradient (including high Ca2+ concentration ~400 uM vs. cytoplasmic ~100 nM): (1) Pore ring: The central channel of Sec61alpha contains a constriction formed by six hydrophobic amino acids (predominantly isoleucine residues) that project inward like a gasket. This ring seals around the translocating polypeptide, preventing ion leakage during active translocation. (2) Plug helix: When the channel is idle (no substrate), a short alpha-helix (TM2a) blocks the lumenal end of the pore, preventing passive ion flux. Upon signal peptide insertion and channel opening, the plug is displaced. (3) BiP/GRP78: The lumenal Hsp70 chaperone BiP has been proposed to seal the lumenal side of the translocon during pauses in translocation, providing an additional barrier. BiP associates with the Sec63 J-domain protein complex near the translocon. (4) Ribosome-translocon junction: The ribosome docked at the cytoplasmic face creates a tight seal that prevents leakage from the cytoplasmic side. The ribosomal exit tunnel aligns with the Sec61 channel. (5) Post-translational regulation: When translocation is complete, the channel closes, the plug reinserts, and the pore ring returns to its constricted state. Failure to maintain the seal leads to ER calcium depletion and UPR activation.

questions.question: During initiation of bacterial translation, three initiation factors (IF1, IF2, IF3) play distinct roles. IF2 is a GTPase that delivers fMet-tRNA to the P site. What is the specific function of IF3 in translation initiation?
options: IF3 catalyzes the formylation of methionine on the initiator tRNA

IF3 binds the 30S subunit and prevents premature association with the 50S subunit, ensures fidelity of start codon selection by destabilizing 30S-mRNA complexes with non-AUG codons in the P site, and dissociates after 50S joining to complete 70S formation
IF3 is the primary factor that recognizes the Shine-Dalgarno sequence
IF3 serves as a structural component of the 50S subunit
questions.explanation: IF3 (Initiation Factor 3) is a critical component of bacterial translation initiation with multiple functions: (1) Anti-association activity: IF3 binds to the 30S subunit (specifically near the platform, interacting with h44, h45, and h24 of 16S rRNA) and prevents premature 30S-50S association into empty 70S ribosomes. This ensures that free 30S subunits are available to begin new rounds of initiation. (2) Start codon fidelity: IF3 acts as a fidelity factor for start codon selection. It destabilizes 30S initiation complexes formed with non-canonical start codons (non-AUG). When the 30S-mRNA complex has the correct AUG codon paired with fMet-tRNA anticodon in the P site, the complex is stable enough to resist IF3's destabilizing activity. But if a non-AUG codon occupies the P site, IF3 promotes dissociation of the unstable complex. This proofreading mechanism ensures that translation initiates at the correct start codon. (3) Ribosome recycling: After translation termination, IF3 binds to the 30S subunit (following RRF/EF-G-mediated splitting of the post-termination 70S complex) and promotes dissociation of deacylated tRNA and mRNA from the 30S subunit. (4) IF3 dissociation: Upon correct 30S initiation complex formation (30S-mRNA-fMet-tRNA-IF2-GTP), IF3 must dissociate to allow 50S subunit joining. GTP hydrolysis by IF2 upon 50S association triggers IF3 release, completing 70S initiation complex formation.

questions.question: Mutagenesis studies have shown that the sickle cell allele (HbS) provides heterozygote advantage against Plasmodium falciparum malaria. From a molecular genetics perspective, the HbS mutation (GAG→GTG encoding Glu6Val in beta-globin) is classified as which type of mutation?
options: A frameshift mutation caused by a single nucleotide deletion
A silent mutation that does not affect the protein sequence

A missense mutation — a single nucleotide substitution that changes one amino acid to a different amino acid, specifically a non-conservative change from a negatively charged hydrophilic residue (glutamic acid) to a nonpolar hydrophobic residue (valine)
A nonsense mutation that introduces a premature stop codon
questions.explanation: The sickle cell mutation is one of the best-characterized single nucleotide mutations in human genetics and serves as a textbook example of a missense mutation: (1) DNA level: The mutation is a single nucleotide substitution (point mutation) in the sixth codon of the beta-globin gene: GAG → GTG (in DNA), or GAG → GUG (in mRNA). This is specifically a transversion (purine A → pyrimidine-paired T/U at the DNA level, but actually A→T change in the sense strand). (2) Protein level: The codon change converts glutamic acid (Glu, E) at position 6 to valine (Val, V). Since it changes one amino acid to a different one, it is classified as a missense mutation. (3) Non-conservative nature: Glutamic acid is negatively charged (pKa ~4.1) and hydrophilic, while valine is nonpolar and hydrophobic. This dramatic change in chemical properties is classified as a non-conservative substitution — the replacement amino acid has fundamentally different properties from the original. This non-conservative change is what enables the pathological hydrophobic interaction between HbS molecules. (4) Heterozygote advantage: In HbAS carriers (sickle cell trait), the presence of both HbA and HbS provides protection against severe P. falciparum malaria because: sickling of infected red blood cells promotes their clearance, reduced parasite growth in cells with HbS, and enhanced immune recognition of infected sickled cells. This balancing selection maintains the HbS allele at high frequency in malaria-endemic regions.

questions.question: Chaperone-mediated autophagy (CMA) is a selective protein degradation pathway that differs from macroautophagy and the ubiquitin-proteasome system. How are substrate proteins selected for CMA?
options: All misfolded proteins are automatically targeted to CMA without any selection signal
Proteins are randomly engulfed by autophagosomes based on proximity to the lysosome

Substrate proteins contain a KFERQ-like pentapeptide motif in their sequence that is recognized by the cytoplasmic chaperone Hsc70; the Hsc70-substrate complex docks with the lysosomal membrane receptor LAMP2A, which oligomerizes to form a translocation channel for direct substrate unfolding and import into the lysosomal lumen for degradation
CMA substrates are selected by ubiquitination with K63-linked chains
questions.explanation: Chaperone-mediated autophagy (CMA) is a highly selective form of lysosomal protein degradation that operates through a unique mechanism: (1) Substrate recognition: CMA substrates contain a KFERQ-like pentapeptide motif (biochemically defined as: [KR]-[FLIVJ]-[ED]-[KR]-Q, or variants). This motif is present in approximately 30% of cytoplasmic proteins, though it may be cryptically buried and only exposed upon protein damage or partial unfolding. (2) Cytoplasmic recognition: The constitutively expressed chaperone Hsc70 (heat shock cognate 70, the constitutive Hsp70 family member) recognizes and binds the KFERQ motif along with co-chaperones (Hsp40, Hsp90, Hip, Hop, BAG1). (3) Lysosomal targeting: The Hsc70-substrate complex docks at the lysosomal membrane by binding to the cytoplasmic tail of LAMP2A (Lysosome-Associated Membrane Protein type 2A). This interaction is the rate-limiting step. (4) LAMP2A multimerization: Substrate binding triggers LAMP2A monomers to oligomerize into a ~700 kDa translocation complex. (5) Substrate unfolding and translocation: The substrate must be unfolded to cross the lysosomal membrane. Hsc70 assists in unfolding on the cytoplasmic side. A resident form of Hsc70 inside the lysosomal lumen (lys-Hsc70) pulls the substrate through. (6) Degradation: Once inside, lysosomal proteases (cathepsins) degrade the substrate. (7) CMA activity increases during prolonged starvation (>10 hours, after macroautophagy peaks), oxidative stress, and aging-related conditions.

questions.question: The concept of reading frame is fundamental to understanding the genetic code. A single mRNA can theoretically be read in three different reading frames (from the same strand). What prevents ribosomes from initiating translation in incorrect reading frames in both bacteria and eukaryotes?
options: The ribosome can read all three frames simultaneously and selects the correct one post-translationally
Only one reading frame produces a stable mRNA; the other two are degraded during transcription
Special tRNAs called frame-maintenance factors bind between codons to prevent slippage

In bacteria, the Shine-Dalgarno sequence positions the ribosome to place a specific AUG in the P site, defining the reading frame; in eukaryotes, scanning from the 5' cap to the first AUG in a favorable Kozak context determines the frame; once established, the ribosome maintains frame by moving exactly three nucleotides per translocation step
questions.explanation: Reading frame establishment and maintenance are critical for accurate protein synthesis. The mechanisms differ between bacteria and eukaryotes but share the principle of AUG selection: Bacteria — Shine-Dalgarno-mediated frame setting: (1) The Shine-Dalgarno sequence (AGGAGG or variant) base-pairs with the anti-Shine-Dalgarno sequence on 16S rRNA, positioning the 30S subunit so that a specific AUG (typically 5-10 nucleotides downstream) is placed directly in the P site. (2) fMet-tRNA(fMet) base-pairs with this AUG, establishing the reading frame. (3) All subsequent codons are read in this frame because translocation moves the ribosome exactly 3 nucleotides at a time. Eukaryotes — cap-dependent scanning: (1) The 43S pre-initiation complex is recruited to the 5' cap via eIF4F. (2) The complex scans 5' to 3' until it encounters the first AUG in a favorable Kozak context. (3) Met-tRNA(i) base-pairs with this AUG in the P site, establishing the frame. Frame maintenance during elongation: (1) The ribosome's decoding center in the 30S/40S subunit ensures precise codon-anticodon recognition through induced-fit mechanisms. (2) EF-G/eEF2-mediated translocation moves the ribosome exactly one codon (3 nt) per cycle. (3) The mRNA is threaded through the mRNA channel with contact points that maintain precise register. (4) Frameshifting errors occur at ~10^-5 frequency per codon, maintaining reading frame fidelity. When programmed frameshifting does occur (retroviruses, some cellular genes), it requires specific slippery sequences and RNA structures to overcome this inherent frame maintenance.
